status_message:
Kez today raised the case of Elaine Hanby from Nairn during First Minister's Questions.

Mrs Hanby is the chair of the Royal Navy and Royal Marines Widows' Association, and was diagnosed with a cataract two years ago. She has been told to expect a 12-month wait for a consultation, even though the SNP promises no patient should wait longer than 12 weeks.

The wait is so bad that Mrs Hanby is considering going to Europe for treatment.

All this comes in the week the Chair of BMA Scotland warned our NHS is at 'breaking point' and the worst A&E waiting times were published in two years.

Instead of dividing Scotland by rerunning the arguments for a second independence referendum, the SNP should focus on running our NHS.
link_name: Doctors are getting sick of SNP spin abour our NHS

status_message:
Ahead of tomorrow's parliamentary debate on Supporting Local Communities(fuel poverty and energy efficiency) please sign up to the Energy Action Scotland(EAS)  Thunderclap to reset the fuel poverty target in Scotland. 

Energy Action Scotland is aiming to have a strong message delivered across social media on the last day of November 2016 to urge Scottish Ministers to reset the fuel poverty target.
 
Energy Action Scotland (EAS) is the national charity which campaigns to end fuel poverty and works to promote warm, dry homes for all.
 
The Scottish Government was required to eradicate fuel poverty by November 2016 under the Housing (Scotland) Act 2001.
The Scottish Government announced in June this year that it wasn't going to meet the target. In fact fuel poverty levels in Scotland are rising. The most recent figures show that 34.9% of the population are in fuel poverty.  Fuel poverty means living in a cold, damp home. Fuel poverty results in misery, ill health, debt and discomfort.

The URL for the Thunderclap is at:

http://bit.ly/2gcvmF2

The SNP government has been accused of 'shameful cuts' as funding for vital jobs schemes are slashed.

Places available through the Skills Development Scotland 'employability fund' have been reduced from 17,302 to 11,397 – a 34 per cent cut.

The fund enables local training providers to work with employers to understand their skills needs and help them find and train the right individuals.

Kez has called for more investment in young people as she visited the closure-threatened Blackburn Local Employment Scheme (BLES) in West Lothian.

For more than 30 years BLES has helped 16 to 18-year-olds - many of whom need additional support - to gain recognised qualifications.
However the charity now faces closure because of SNP Government funding cuts

Commenting on World Mental Health Day, Labour Inequalities spokesperson Monica Lennon said:

"Mental health should be every bit as important to government policy as physical health."

"Scotland has made some strides in removing the taboos and stigma associated with mental health, but recent findings in the Scottish Social Attitudes Survey still show we have a way to go, particularly in understanding depression."

"The SNP government in Edinburgh so far simply has not been good enough on mental health. The waiting times figures for treatment for those with mental health conditions are nothing short of scandalous and simply would not be tolerated if replicated in A&E wards or GP surgeries, and further cuts to local services will only make this worse."

"Scotland's forthcoming mental health strategy is an opportunity to start to get things right, all parties say they support parity for mental health, now it's time to deliver it."

status_message:
Kez writing in The Times this past weekend..

There should be a renewed focus on the day job from the SNP 

This weekend marks the second anniversary of the SNP's referendum on Scottish independence that divided our nation.
Two years on, the divisions caused by that historic contest have not healed.

On social media and in the real word, the scars that are Alex Salmond's political legacy remain painfully obvious.
Anonymous internet users hurl abuse at people they will never meet, politicians from all parties are on the receiving end of foul language, and too many people across Scotland feel they must now choose between being labelled a Unionist or a nationalist.

That is not why I got into politics, and it is not why people in the Labour Party got into politics. I want to make a difference to the public services that so many of us rely on, in our hospitals, care homes, our classrooms and elsewhere.

status_message:
Last night Jackie Baillie MSP led a debate in the Scottish Parliament to oppose the proposed cuts at the Vale of Leven Hospital.
The health board previously said that local GPs would play a part in promoting the Vale of Leven Hospital's maternity unit and encouraging women to use local services. 

However our survey of local practices shows that three quarters of local GPs were not even aware of any marketing activity taking place in their practices at the time of Vision for the Vale. This blows a huge hole through the health board's claims to have actively promoted the services at our local hospital.

We are also campaigning against the following cuts:

- closure of Lightburn Hospital.
- closure of maternity services at Vale of Leven Hospital and Inverclyde Hospital.
- downgrading of paediatric services at the Royal Alexandria Hospital.
- closure on inpatient services at the Centre for Integrated Care at the Gartnaval.
- downgrading of orthopaedics services at Monklands Hospital.

Read our dossier on these cuts here ☞ http://bit.ly/NHSDossier

These cuts will have a massive impact on local services.  How are you affected by these cuts? We'd like to hear your stories.  Email us at Scotland@labour.org.uk if you'd be willing to share yours.

You can watch last nights debate here ☞ http://bit.ly/2cHzbjY

Under Labour's plans, the Scottish Graduation Certificate would be a qualification gained at the senior phase of secondary school and would involve vocational courses, work experience, voluntary achievement and traditional exams.

Scottish pupils deserve a 'level playing field' on appeal charges.

Scottish Labour have made a fresh call to scrap charges for exam appeals as research shows that private school pupils are three times as likely to appeal a grade as state school pupils.
Exam appeals costs were met centrally in Scotland until 2014. Rates of appeal were previously similar in state and independent sector schools.  In 2014 the SNP Government introduced a fee if an appeal, or an exam 'review', is carried out but no change is made to the grade awarded. 

Read more here ➜ http://bit.ly/2aUEkRB

All children under 5 should have free access to meningitis B vaccinations 

All children under 5 should have free access to meningitis B vaccinations, Scottish Labour said today.  Under current rules, introduced by the SNP Government, free vaccinations against meningitis B are only available to children born after July 1 2015.

Parents of children born before that day  -  even one day – have to pay privately with the cost in some instances being more than £200 per child.

Ian Murray appointed as Scottish Labour Westminster Spokesperson
 
Scottish Labour Leader Kezia Dugdale has today appointed Ian Murray MP to the Scottish Shadow Cabinet as Scottish Labour's Westminster Spokesperson.

Commenting on the appointment, Kezia Dugdale said:
"I'm pleased to welcome Ian to my Shadow Cabinet. As Scotland's only Labour MP, Ian has a crucial role to play in representing Scotland's interests at Westminster and working to strengthen our party as he has done since he was re-elected last year."
Ian Murray MP said:

"I look forward to continuing to play my part in rebuilding the fortunes of the Scottish Labour Party. As we look towards the Local Government elections and the next UK General Election, we have to do all we can to strengthen our party, reach out to communities all across Scotland, and speak to the vast majority of working people who need a Labour Government in Scotland and across the UK. Following the EU referendum vote, we also need to stand up for those people who voted to remain and understand why over a million Scots voted to leave the EU."

- See more at: http://www.scottishlabour.org.uk/blog/entry/ian-murray-appointed-as-scottish-labour-westminster-spokesperson#sthash.vm9e0Jtx.dpuf
link_name: Ian Murray appointed as Scottish Labour Westminster Spokesperson

status_message:
Scottish Labour Leader, Kezia Dugdale, has spoken following the attack last night in France:

"The people of France have suffered devastation and loss in recent years that no nation should have to go through. Once again the thoughts and prayers of everybody in Scottish Labour and across the country are with the people of France.

"The video of terrified children and their parents running from danger are haunting. It's an image that will live with me for the rest of my life. To see such innocence destroyed by someone who is motivated by hatred and bigotry is heart-breaking.

"We cannot give in to terror. We cannot cede an inch to those who seek to change our way of live through violence, intolerance and hatred. Difficult though it may be in the immediate aftermath of such a horrific attack, we must resolve to never give in to the terrorists by rejecting the values underpinning or democracy. Only by staying true to who we are - a tolerant, free society - can we hope to defeat those who wish to do us harm."

link_name: "We have to understand why more than a million Scots took the risk of a vote to leave the EU"

status_message:
Kez speaking after the Edinburgh Pride 2016 March...

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NtRCsbA5fec

'I marched to with a sense of solidarity with the LGBT community in America, deeply scarred by the brutal terrorist attacks in Orlando.

But I also marched with pride and hope. Proud of the incredible journey Scotland has been on since the row over section 28 (2a) Scotland. That referendum battle over the teaching of homosexuality in schools may be nearly 20 years old now, but it's still all too raw for many.

Hope for the future, and for what further progress we can achieve in Scotland. We have not one but four party leaders who identify as LGBT, and we can use that power to create an inclusive society. Wherever can be who they are, safely and at peace with the world."
link_name: Kez speaking after leading the Edinburgh Pride March 2016.

status_message: Before the main Pride march started Kez had a few words of advice for the huge crowd!

Thanks to everyone who came and joined Kez and the Scottish Labour team at Edinburgh Pride on Saturday. It was a brilliant day opened and led by Kez. This year's event included a moving tribute to the victims of last months mass shooting in a gay nightclub in Orlando.

Speaking after the event Kez said-

"This year's Pride march was always going to be big in light of the horrific attacks in Orlando just a few weeks ago, but I wasn't prepared for it to be quite so big!

Within minutes of the Queen leaving the Parliament for the Palace, the Royal Mile was awash with drag kings and queens, Edinburgh's gay rugby club and choir. The racing sound of motorbikes and a dance float in amongst thousands of marchers. Gay, straight, curious - all united by one simple emotion - Pride.

I spoke at the start of the march for the first time and it was a pretty special moment for me having just come out during the election campaign. I told the crowds that I was marching with pride but also with anger, solidarity and hope.Anger at the fact that there are still countless countries in the world where it's illegal to be gay. Countries where the crime of being attracted to someone of the same sex is still punishable by death.

I marched to with a sense of solidarity with the LGBT community in America, deeply scarred by the brutal terrorist attacks in Orlando.
But I also marched with pride and hope. Proud of the incredible journey Scotland has been on since the row over section 28 (2a) Scotland. That referendum battle over the teaching of homosexuality in schools may be nearly 20 years old now, but it's still all too raw for many.

Hope for the future, and for what further progress we can achieve in Scotland. We have not one but four party leaders who identify as LGBT, and we can use that power to create an inclusive society. Wherever can be who they are, safely and at peace with the world."

status_message:

"Our job, as at the birth of this Parliament, is to shape the future"

Read more here: http://bit.ly/1XjmOZy
Watch live as Kezia Dugdale, Alan Johnson and Scottish Labour's MEPs launch our campaign to remain in the EU.

TODAY we launch #LabourInForScotland 🌹❤️🇪🇺
We must make EU arguments of the heart as well as the head.

Kezia will formally launch the Labour In campaign in Scotland today by urging people not to get complacent in the face of strong poll ratings for a vote to remain in the EU.

At an event in Edinburgh to launch Scottish Labour's pro-EU campaign with Alan Johnson, Chair of Labour In for Britain, Kezia Dugdale will urge people to get out and make the positive case for staying in the EU.

The Scottish Labour leader will also say that although the economic case for staying in the EU is overwhelming, the emotional arguments for remaining in the EU must also be made.

Kezia will say:

"Don't listen to those who say that Scotland is going to vote overwhelmingly to remain in the EU on 23 June.

"The last few weeks have taught us again not to read polls as prediction, as if we needed another lesson after the general election. There's no such thing as a guaranteed win in politics. There can be no complacency when the future of our nation is at stake.

"We may be weary as a nation after three national campaigns in as many years, but we need to do it all over again in the next few weeks.

"We will make the case with passion and conviction."

Addressing the emotional case for staying in the EU, Kezia Dugdale will say:

"In this debate we must win the head arguments but they have to be combined with a story that reaches people's hearts.

"We will make the economic case: that trade with the EU is essential to Scottish jobs, second only to our domestic market in the UK.

"We will argue the case for workers' rights - that Europe guarantees basic standards at work for millions of Scottish workers, regardless of who is in government.

"We will argue that in a world of constant change and confusing new threats, we are more secure in bigger alliances than alone.

"We will make these arguments, but we will also argue that there is something beautiful about being part of this European family. It isn't found in the grey offices of officials in Brussels or in the columns of national balance sheets, but in lives made more colourful, more fulfilling and more exciting in the cities and towns of Scotland, the UK and 27 other nations.

"My generation, and that of my parents before me, have become so used to that that we don't stop to wonder at the achievement the EU represents.

"From Scandinavia to the Aegean. From the Balearic Islands to the Arctic Circle. From the Carpathians to the Highlands. We cooperate, sharing freedom, together. It's a continent whose history is written in conflict and chaos but is now defined by peace and prosperity.

"We have been part of that. We built that. It's not perfect but it is as extraordinary an achievement as any in our history.

"We are a more European country for having built that union. We are richer for it. Not just the bump in our GDP, as important as that is, but richer for the shared experiences, the mixing of cultures, the people we've come to know, the amazing experiences and opportunities that the EU has brought to us.

"I fear we may not realise that until it's gone."

SIGN UP TO GET INVOLVED NOW: www.scottishlabour.org.uk/volunteering

We are Labour In for Scotland. Get involved in our campaign now and sign up to volunteer: 

www.scottishlabour.org.uk/volunteering

Today marks a fresh start for the Labour Party at Holyrood.

Scottish Labour's new MSPs will start work at Holyrood today as the party prepares to take the fight to the SNP from opposition.

Four of Scottish Labour's new group of MSPs have never served in the Scottish or UK Parliament before. They come from careers in business, the charity sector, local government and trade unions.

Speaking ahead of the new MSPs arriving in Holyrood, Kezia said:

"Today marks a fresh start for the Labour Party at Holyrood. Labour will lead progressive opposition to the SNP and our new MSPs – who come with experience from outside politics – will be critical to that success.

"We need all their talents to rebuild for the long term. Over the next five years the Scottish Parliament will take responsibility for a whole host of new powers, including over tax and welfare.

"With a minority SNP government, we will put forward progressive proposals for how the new Parliament should use those powers in the best interests of the people of Scotland. If the SNP are looking for our support they will need to be bold and radical in how they use the new powers of the Parliament."

Find out more about our new MSPs here: http://www.scottishlabour.org.uk/blog/entry/today-marks-a-fresh-start-for-the-labour-party#sthash.MI3ElvdC.dpuf

We will fight for a more effective Scottish Parliament 

Our manifesto contained many proposals for reforming the Scottish Parliament that received backing from all opposition parties. 

We will work with other parties to make them a reality.

Scottish Labour will be a positive and effective opposition and one of the first jobs of opposition is to hold the Government to account and to hold them responsible for the decisions they are making. 

To do that, we need a Scottish Parliament where the many voices of opposition – from all parties – are heard.

As a start, the Presiding Officer and the majority of committee convenorships should not come from the governing party. 

We saw in the last term that SNP dominated committees did not provide anywhere near the level of scrutiny that the Government's work required. We will work to change that.

But we must go further. People require confidence that the politicians they elect to serve are giving them the full attention they deserve. 

Being a member of the Scottish Parliament is an immense privilege and it should be the only job that MSPs do. That is why we will push for a ban on MSPs holding second jobs, including paid directorships and consultancies.

Read more here: http://www.scottishlabour.org.uk/blog/entry/we-will-fight-for-a-more-effective-scottish-parliament

We fought for what we believe in at this election - for using the powers of the Scottish Parliament to invest in the future of our economy - and we'll continue to stand up for what we believe in.

Be part of our movement and stand up with us:
https://scotlandjoin.labour.org.uk/

Campaigning in Edinburgh today, Kezia has said her plans to tax the richest 1% to invest in education and stop the cuts to public services would offer transformational change for Scotland's economy.

By contrast, other parties want to define the next five years about the arguments of the past.

Every Labour MSP sent to Holyrood would be a voice for greater investment in education and public services.

Kezia said:

"Tomorrow we can vote to stop the cuts. In the next five years we can use the new powers of our parliament to transform our economy. We can invest in education to give our young people the skills they need to compete for the jobs of the future.

"The best future for our country is as a high wage, high skill economy. To get there we need to invest in cutting the gap between the richest and the rest in our classrooms, and we need to stop the cuts to public services.

"Other parties want to spend the next five years arguing about the past, when Scotland just wants to move on and help our people get on. I have three priories for the next five years – use the new powers of our Parliament to tax the richest 1% so we can invest in schools, and stop the cuts to public services. "To make the next five years about the future rather than our past people have to use both their votes for Labour. A vote for anyone else will mean more cuts. Our plan to end the housing crisis will support nearly 50,000 jobs.

We'll also introduce new measures in the private rented sector to protect tenants from bad landlords and help first time buyers save for a deposit.

NEWS: Today, the UK Government has agreed to Labour's Lords amendments on the Trade Union Bill. 

On the news, Ian Murray MP said: 
"The Trade Union Bill was an unjust and undemocratic attack on workers' and trades unions' rights across the country. That is why Labour has fought this Bill every step of the way.

"We are pleased that the Government has listened to the arguments we have made in the Commons and Lords, and taken account of the proposals in the report of the cross-party House of Lords joint committee set up by Labour's Lords amendments.

"Our efforts in the Lords have ensured that many of the worst elements – the restrictions to facilities time and check off and the attack on political funds – have been removed. 

"In Scotland, Labour councils led opposition to the Bill by passing motions of non-compliance. And Labour MSPs strained every sinew to block the passage of the Bill, petitioning the Scottish Parliament to change the rules to allow for a legislative consent motion – a proposal that was blocked by the SNP, the Liberal Democrats and the Tories.

"Labour in Scotland and across the UK will always fight for the rights of working people and solidarity with our friends in the trade union movement."

READ MORE: http://www.scottishlabour.org.uk/blog/entry/our-fight-against-the-tories-trade-union-bill#sthash.4vbhXncL.dpuf

BREAKING: Every child deserves a fair start in life - that's why our manifesto, released today, will to pledge to fund a breakfast club in every primary school in Scotland. 🍞🍎🍴👦👧

Schools across Scotland will be provided with funds for a breakfast club. This money will be in addition to any resources currently used for breakfast clubs at the moment and will average £6,500. For schools already with a breakfast club this will allow for an expansion. For those schools currently without a breakfast club it will allow one to be established.

It would be for individual schools to decide how to use the money for the breakfast club - for example the school can decide the hours the club runs. It will be the first step in developing a childcare policy for Scotland that fits around the lives of parents, not just on an election leaflet.

Labour's manifesto will also protect existing plans to increase pre-school entitlement to 30 hours of free childcare a week, but will emphasise the need for flexible and affordable wrap-around childcare.

Our other pledges for children include:

→ A Fair Start Fund from the 50p top rate of tax on those earning more than £150,000 a year to invest in cutting the attainment gap between the richest and rest in our classrooms
→ Protection of the education budget in real terms
→ Reforming the senior phase of school with a Scottish Graduation Certificate involving vocational courses, work experience and traditional exams. This would allow formal recognition for young people with fewer traditional qualifications
→ Funding primary school teachers to go on a basic coding course to empower them to introduce it to pupils as early as possible
→ Scrapping charges for exam appeals
→ Protecting free university tuition
→ Reverse the SNP's cuts to bursaries for the poorest students in Higher Education
→ Guarantee support for students in Further Education

TUNE IN all morning on our Facebook and Twitter to watch live coverage of the manifesto launch. 

http://www.scottishlabour.org.uk/blog/entry/every-child-deserves-a-fair-start-in-life#sthash.BhIhkUS6.dpuf

READ: Kez in today's Daily Record

"If the Tory Government delivers anything short of what they promised then it will be a deep betrayal to the workers on the Clyde and their families.

Before the election, the Labour Party was absolutely clear that we would meet the promises we made to the shipbuilding industry, and it's bitterly disappointing that we aren't in Government now to see that promise through.

As Leader of the Labour Party, I won't play politics with these jobs and our shipbuilding industry. It's far too important for that. But I won't stay silent when people propose actions that would put a at risk – whether that's the UK Government's delay or the SNP's plans for independence.

This week, I plan to visit the yards again to speak with the workers – many of whom I stood side by side with when they campaigned against independence to secure their industry. I want to hear from them directly about what this delay will mean for them and their families and see what more I can do to help. .

These Frigates must be delivered on the Clyde as promised. We won't stand for anything less."
link_name: If the Tories deliver short of what they promised then it will be a betrayal to workers on the Clyde

ANNOUNCED TODAY: Labour will deliver better support for Scotland's carers. 

Scotland's carers don't fit a stereotype; they come from all over Scotland and from all walks of life. 

Whilst the type of people who are unpaid carers changes from family to family, every single one of them deserve better support from the next Scottish Government.

Looking after a vulnerable family member or loved one can be exhausting and stressful. Scotland's unpaid carers aren't looking to be treated as victims – they just want the same rights as everyone else. 

That's while we will establish a Carers' Commissioner to champion their cause and ensure the rights they have are backed up by the proper resources.

Find out more about our plans: http://www.scottishlabour.org.uk/blog/entry/labour-will-deliver-better-support-for-scotlands-carers

status_message:
Ken Macintosh: "Everyone should have the chance to own their own home if they work hard and save up, not just those who can rely on financial support from their parents.

"So many young people in Scotland are stuck in a cycle from which they can't escape. They end up renting to save for a deposit, but the rent is so high they simply can't put enough money away.

"That's why Labour will offer to help to first time buyers save towards a deposit, with up to £3,000 of extra support for those who save every month.

"That's the positive difference we can make with the new powers coming to the Scottish Parliament. Faced with the choice between using the powers of the Scottish Parliament to invest in our future or carrying on with the cuts, Labour will use the powers."
link_name: We'll help young people get a foot on the housing ladder

WATCH: Our TV broadcast for the Scottish Parliament election: We can do things differently.

It features an interview with Kezia Dugdale in her home in Lochend, Edinburgh, talking about her belief in the power of education, the influence of her parents who were both teachers and her aspirations for every child across Scotland.

She also addresses attacks on her and the Labour Party's policies by the SNP and the Tories, declaring that she is "not going to stop, because we can't afford to cut into our schools, to cut into our children's future – it doesn't have to be this way, we can make different choices."

The film will be broadcast today at the following times:

- 18.55 on BBC One
- 17.55 on BBC Two
- 18.25 on STV

Kez will also address people across Scotland directly in a radio broadcast tonight at 18.28 on BBC Radio Scotland.

We'll put dignity at the heart of Scotland's social security system.

Kezia Dugdale has outlined plans to give vulnerable Scots the option of either cash or in kind payments through the Scottish Welfare Fund.

The move has previously been supported by anti-poverty charities including the Child Poverty Action Group, Scottish Council for Voluntary Organisations and the Poverty Alliance.

The current system does not allow claimants to the Scottish Welfare Fund to choose cash payments, which third sector groups have argued decreases independence for claimants and can ultimately be more costly.

Kezia also outlined our further plans for a fairer social security system, including

- Ensuring that children leaving care and going into higher education get a full grant, and not the bare minimum.
- Abolishing the bedroom tax once and for all, using new powers over Universal Credit.
- Supporting carers by raising carers' allowance to the same level as Jobseekers' Allowance.
- Tackling child poverty by doubling the Sure Start maternity grant, increasing its value to £1,030.

http://www.scottishlabour.org.uk/blog/entry/we-will-put-dignity-at-the-heart-of-scotlands-social-security-system

With less than three weeks until polling day, she laid out the choice facing people across Scotland and made clear that "any Labour Scottish Government will increase spending on public services in Scotland."

Today is Climate Day - and to mark it Kezia has outlined how a vote for Labour is a vote for a greener Scotland.

It's time to deliver on Scotland's world leading ambitions on climate change.

Our plan for a greener Scotland includes:
→ A ban on fracking
→ A ground-breaking Warm Homes Act to update regulations to tackle fuel poverty by driving up energy and insulation standards
→ Cancelling the SNP's plan to cut air passenger duty which will lead to an annual increase in greenhouse gas emissions of 50,000 tonnes.

Climate change is the great challenge for this generation, and the next Scottish Government must take action to tackle it now. 

Kezia said:
"The greatest global challenge facing my generation is climate change. The next Scottish Government needs to offer more than warms words; it needs to deliver real change.

"A Labour Scottish Government will ban fracking. Science tells us the last thing our climate needs is another fossil fuel. With Labour there will be no ifs, no buts, no fracking in Scotland.

"The SNP's approach to climate change is similar to its whole approach to government - set a target, miss it and then set an even tougher target in the hope nobody notices.

"Labour will deliver a Scottish Government that finally implements the policies to match our ambitions on the environment and climate change. Labour will use the powers to deliver a greener, fairer Scotland."

READ MORE: http://www.scottishlabour.org.uk/blog/entry/a-vote-for-labour-is-a-vote-for-a-greener-scotland

ANNOUNCED TODAY: Our pledge for £40 million a year for an after-school sports 'revolution'

A Labour Scottish Government will invest £40 million a year in after-school sports clubs.

Labour will use the Barnett consequentials from the recently announced sugar tax to deliver funding worth an average of over £100,000 per secondary school, dependent on school rolls.

This investment will be part of a wider move to make local schools and the associated facilities the hub of community sport activity as part of Labour's plans to use the new powers of the Scottish Parliament to stop the cuts.

Kezia said:
"This can be a revolution for after-school sport in Scotland. The positive benefits of sport and healthier lifestyles for our young people will be felt all across our country, from less pressure on our NHS to higher achievement in our classrooms.

"Every single young person in Scotland deserves the best possible start in life. With a Labour Scottish Government that will mean a world class education in the classroom and the opportunity to get involved in sport after school.

"After-school clubs and extracurricular activities are where young people find out who they are and what they're good at. Cutting education will cut the opportunities our children enjoy. That's why Labour will use the new powers to stop the cuts and why we will invest £40 million a year in after-school sports clubs.
 
"That kind of investment in sport and healthier lifestyles will have a transformational impact in our classrooms, in our health service and in our economy – if we unearth a few World Cup winners, Wimbledon champions or gold medallists along the way that'll be a bonus.

"We'll put sport at the heart of communities again by stopping the cuts to schools and local services. Faced with the choice between using the powers of the Scottish Parliament to invest in the future or carrying on the SNP's cuts, Labour will use the powers to stop the cuts."
WATCH: Kez in Rutherglen yesterday, speaking about how we'll use the powers to stop the cuts.

We will stop the cuts to the services children need to get the best possible start in life.

Under the SNP budget hundreds of millions of pounds will be cut from schools and local services across Scotland, putting after school sports clubs and extracurricular activities at risk.

Kezia visited a toddler's football group where she outlined her plan to stop the cuts by taking different and fairer decisions on tax – including reversing George Osborne's tax cut for the top 1% by setting a 50p top rate of tax for those earning more than £150,000 a year.

Kezia said:
"I want every single young person to get the best possible start in life. That means a world class education in the classroom but it also means children getting the opportunity to try something new. After-school clubs and extracurricular activities are where young people find out who they are and what they're good at. Cutting education will cut the opportunities our children enjoy.

"As the experts at IPPR Scotland confirmed, because the SNP refuse to use the new powers of the Scottish Parliament they will be forced to make billions of pounds of cuts to services if they are re-elected.

"We don't have to accept that. We can take a different path to Tory austerity by using the powers of the Scottish Parliament. Labour will reverse the tax cut for the top 1% so we can stop the cuts and invest in schools. The SNP won't tax the top 1% and it'll be our children who lose out.

"Faced with the choice between using the powers of the Scottish Parliament to invest in the future or carrying on the SNP's cuts, Labour will use the powers to stop the cuts."

ANNOUNCED TODAY: Women pensioners will not be worse off under a future Labour Scottish Government.

Thousands of women across Scotland face being left worse off because of changes to the state pension age and the fast-tracked introduction of the new single-tier State Pension. 

Under Labour's plans, the cohort of women affected would receive a top up to their pension using the new powers of the Scottish Parliament. This will be paid for by reversing George Osborne's changes to the higher rate threshold.

We will not give up the fight against these changes at Westminster, but will not stand by when we have the powers to make a difference to the thousands of women affected across Scotland.

Find out more: http://www.scottishlabour.org.uk/blog/entry/women-pensioners-will-not-be-worse-off-under-a-future-labour-scottish-gover#sthash.F0k842Nh.dpuf

On the day of their manifesto release, Ruth Davidson's Tories need to spell out the cost of their plan for secret taxes on the sick and on students.

Instead of setting out a vision for the NHS Ruth Davidson wants to introduce a tax on the sick by reintroducing prescription charges.

The Tories think education in Scotland is a privilege, not a right, and want to scare off students from poorer backgrounds with by reintroducing tuition fees worth thousands of pounds.

On tax, the defining issue of this election, Ruth Davidson has nothing to say. A vote for the Tories in May is a vote to endorse David Cameron and George Osborne's tax policies. They won't do a thing to stop hundreds of millions of pounds of cuts to schools and public services.

Ruth Davidson wants to take Scotland back to the arguments of the past because she has nothing to say about using the powers to stop the cuts.

It was only a few weeks ago that the Tories claimed to be in a 'taxpayers' alliance' with the SNP - neither of them want to use the new powers to ask the wealthier to pay more to invest in public services.

That simply isn't good enough. Faced with the choice between using the powers of the Scottish Parliament or carrying on the cuts to schools and public services Labour will use the powers to stop the cuts.

At this election, Scottish Labour are clear: with us, it's no ifs, no buts, no fracking.

status_message:
REVEALED: The big lie that the SNP are an anti-austerity party has been exposed today. 

IPPR Scotland today confirmed that Scottish Labour's income tax plans will raise up to £1.2 billion annually. 

Under the SNP's plan just £300 million will be raised, which isn't even close to being enough to stop the cuts to schools and other vital public services. The Tories' plans would raise not a single penny extra in revenue. 

Labour has made an anti-austerity pledge, which means that spending on public services by a Scottish Labour Government will increase in real terms by the next UK General Election. 

Specifically, Labour has committed to protecting the budgets for health and education in real terms. That's only possible because of the fairer choices Labour has made on taxes, including setting a 50p top rate of tax for the richest 1% earning more than £150,000 a year. This would be invested in education. 

Kezia Dugdale said: 

"The IPPR report is a major moment in this election campaign. This independent expert analysis confirms once and for all that only Labour has a real plan to stop the cuts to our public services. 

"Labour's plan would raise more revenue than any other party. We can stop the cuts to public services in Scotland that would mean thousands out of work, fewer staff in our schools and the very fabric of our society put at risk. 

"Cuts to public services will damage our ability to grow the economy and compete with the other nations of the world. Only by investing in education can we give our young people the skills they need to compete for the high skilled jobs of the future. 

"Faced with the choice between using the powers of the Scottish Parliament to invest in our economy or carrying on with the cuts to schools, Labour will use the powers to stop the cuts."

status_message:
WATCH: today Kez met with students at Glasgow University to talk about Scottish Labour's plans to reverse the SNP's cuts to bursaries for the poorest students

A Labour Scottish Government will keep tuition free and reverse the SNP's cuts to Higher Education bursaries for the poorest students so anyone can afford to go to university.

Labour would increase the young student bursary by roughly £900 and the independent student bursary by roughly  £180, reversing the SNP's cuts to student support in Scotland. This restores the value of bursaries in real terms to their highest level in 2012/13.

It will be phased in through above inflation increases over the course of the next parliament and be paid for by Labour's fairer choices on tax to protect the education budget.

Announcing the plans on a visit to Glasgow University today, Kezia said that that a young person's life chances should be determined by their potential, work ethic and talent, not how much money their parents have.

Scottish Labour has also pledged to guarantee financial support for Further Education students.

Kezia said:

"Labour will deliver better student support in Scotland, giving a better and fairer deal to the poorest students.  We will keep tuition free and reverse the SNP's cuts to HigherEducation bursaries for the poorest students so that anyone can afford to go to university.

"We can make that promise because of the different decisions we are taking on tax to invest in education.

"A young person's ability to get on in life should be determined by their potential, work ethic and talent, not how much money their parents have.

"Today in Scotland it is the poorest students who rack up the highest debt in Scotland. Those who start with the least end up owing the most. That's not fair and it stops too many young people getting a degree.

"Faced with the choice between carrying on the SNP's cuts to education or using the powers of the Scottish Parliament, Labour will use the powers to invest in our future.

WATCH: Kez's speech in Portobello on Saturday. 

The new powers of the Scottish Parliament mean cuts to vital public services can be stopped. On Saturday, Kez spoke about how only Labour will end austerity in Scotland

There are billions of pounds of cuts coming to Scotland, but only if we decide that we want to take the same decisions as Tories. If we want to take a different path, we can.

That is the choice we are faced with: will we use the new powers or will we keep cutting into our nation's future prosperity? Labour's choice is to use the powers to invest in the future, to break from austerity.

If we are willing to do things differently. If we are brave enough and bold enough. If we don't mind upsetting the richest so we can look after the rest, then we can break from the austerity that has hurt so many people.

We will guarantee support for students in Further Education.

We will "end the scandal that sees bursary pots run out before the end of the academic year" and promise that support for students in further education will rise with inflation each year.

Kezia Dugdale said:

"Today I want to make absolutely clear that a future Scottish Labour Government will ensure that student support goes to the thousands of young people in Scotland who attend our Further Education colleges.

"Our FE colleges are a vital part of our education system – they give people the skills and opportunities Scotland needs if we are going to be able to compete with the world for the jobs of the future.

"Our announcement today means we will end the scandal that sees bursary pots run out before the end of the academic year. We'll do that by providing additional money to the Scottish Funding Council, instructing them to use it for student support.

"We can make this guarantee because of our choice to raise money to invest in education. That's the choice at this election – between Labour investment or more cuts and continued austerity under the SNP's plan. Because of our choices on tax, we will protect the education budget, including colleges."

TODAY IN PORTOBELLO: Kezia and Jeremy spoke about how only Labour will end austerity in Scotland. 

The new powers of the Scottish Parliament mean cuts to vital public services can be stopped. The SNP refuse to ask the richest 1% to pay their fair share so we can stop the cuts and invest in education.

Kezia said:

"There are billions of pounds of cuts coming to Scotland, but only if we decide that we want to take the same decisions as Tories. If we want to take a different path, we can.

"That is the choice we are faced with: will we use the new powers or will we keep cutting into our nation's future prosperity? Labour's choice is to use the powers to invest in the future, to break from austerity.

"My opponents say we shouldn't do that because the richest will try to avoid paying it. I say that paying tax isn't optional for you or me, so it shouldn't be optional for the richest either. It isn't the job of government to make excuses for why the rich won't pay their taxes; it is the job of government to make sure the rich do pay their taxes.

"If we are willing to do things differently. If we are brave enough and bold enough. If we don't mind upsetting the richest so we can look after the rest, then we can break from the austerity that has hurt so many people."

 Jeremy said: 

"All over the world people are rallying against austerity. In Scotland you have the opportunity, you have the power to break from austerity using the new powers you have. That isn't in doubt.

"The question is whether the Scottish Parliament has enough voices who are willing to use those powers to make that change. 

"Use the powers to do things differently or accept the cuts – that's the simple choice.

"Under Kezia Dugdale Labour has set out a bold plan to use the powers of the Scottish Parliament to stop the cuts. With Labour austerity can end. 

"As things stand the income tax plans set out by the SNP for those powers wouldn't provide a single extra penny for schools or hospitals, for investing in the future of the economy. 

"The anger people feel at the top 1%, from the financial crash caused by bankers, from the revelations of the Panama papers, from growing inequality, is the big issue of our age.

"The SNP have no response to that. It is incredible that the SNP won't ask the richest to pay more. To have gone from arguing last year for taxing the top 1% to accepting Tory arguments against it is a betrayal of everything Nicola Sturgeon promised she stood for at the general election last year.  

"The real anti-austerity alternative in this election is Labour. Every vote for Labour, every Labour MSP elected, will make sure that the Scottish Parliament will use the powers to stop cuts and invest in the future." 

Read more here: http://www.scottishlabour.org.uk/blog/entry/only-labour-will-end-austerity-in-scotland

JUST RELEASED: The Panama papers showed that the rich elite are playing by different rules from the rest of us.

Following the shocking revelation that the Prime Minister has benefitted from money hidden away in tax havens, it's more important than ever for all political leaders to be transparent about their finances.

So today we publish Kezia Dugdale's tax returns and challenge other Scottish party leaders to do the same. These returns show two things:

1. Kez's only income is the salary she receives as an MSP.

2. Kez donates every single penny from her Daily Record column fee to MND Scotland. The money goes direct from the Daily Record to MND Scotland. However, because this is technically classed as income Kez pays tax on this money. So, she personally doesn't receive a single penny for writing the column but pays hundreds of pounds in tax on it anyway.

The following link shows Kez's tax returns. Scroll through to the final page for a series of notes explaining what each number means.

http://www.scottishlabour.org.uk/blog/entry/kezia-dugdales-tax-returns

Our manifesto will seek to ban companies who practice aggressive tax avoidance from winning public contracts in Scotland.

We have confirmed that our manifesto will include a commitment to banning companies who practice aggressive tax avoidance from receiving public contracts.

The move will raise awkward questions for the SNP, who voted against the plans in the last parliament.

Since then millionaire SNP donor Brian Souter has seen his company Stagecoach lose an £11 million tax avoidance case.

Despite branding tax avoidance 'obscene' last year, Nicola Sturgeon has remained silent on the Stagecoach case and on revelations that SNP MP Phil Boswell had used a tax avoidance scheme himself.

The SNP leader has also claimed that there was no point introducing a 50p top rate of tax because the richest will try to avoid it, despite HMRC confirming they will use their powers to ensure people pay their taxes and her own analysis barely detailing tax avoidance.

WATCH: Kezia spoke at a credit union in Paisley today about our plan to tackle poverty.

Speaking at a credit union in Paisley today, Kezia Dugdale was joined by Neil Bibby as she outlined her commitment to sign up in full to the recommendations of the Eisenstadt report.

The report, commissioned by the SNP Government, was first issued in January and set out 15 measures to lift people out of poverty. Nicola Sturgeon said the SNP Government would formally respond before the end of March but failed to do so, with Social Justice spokesperson  Alex Neil confirming this week that the party would not respond until after the election.

The recommendations include a call to "be bold on local tax reform". Scottish Labour will scrap the unfair council tax and replace it with a fairer system. Under the new system 80% of households will pay less than they are paying today.

Kezia also said that any party pledging to tackle poverty and inequality in this election needs to have a clear plan to stop the cuts to public services, and be willing to tax the richest more to protect the poorest.
link_name: The poorest will lose the most unless the next Scottish Government uses the powers to stop the cuts

status_message:
A Scottish Labour Government will end the GP crisis created by the SNP and increase investment in primary care.

We will guarantee every Scot an appointment at a General Practice surgery within 48 hours.

Under the SNP, general practice is facing its worst crisis in a generation, with a quarter of practices struggling to fill vacancies and more than £1 billion in cuts.

Our Labour Party, who established the NHS in the 1940s, will be there to ensure that our health service is fit for the challenges of the 2040s.

The NHS isn't just another policy agenda for Labour, it is part of who we are as a party, our pride in its creation inspires everything else we do.

Instead of the cuts to GPs we've seen in the last decade, our plan for the NHS will guarantee an appointment at your local surgery that you can book online within 48 hours.

Only #BothVotesLabour in May will guarantee an NHS fit for the future.
link_name: This is Scottish Labour's plan for our NHS

status_message:
We need a transport system that works for commuters, not transport bosses.

The next Scottish Labour Government would regulate Scottish bus services for the first time and legislate for an integrated transport system where one smart ticket can take you across Scotland via all modes of transport.

The integrated transport system would be underpinned by new regulation which would provide transport authorities with powers to set service levels and group profitable routes with non-profitable routes.

Despite promising a nationwide smartcard by 2014, the SNP Government has still failed to deliver it with testing only beginning recently and no date set for full roll out. Scottish Labour's plans would be compulsory, apply to all transport operators and would see the roll out within the first year of the new Government and the switch to contactless credit or debit cards by the end of the next Parliament.
link_name: We need a transport system that works for commuters, not transport bosses

status_message:
The average council tax payer will be £111 better off under Labour's plans to scrap the council tax. 

Campaigning in Glasgow today, Kezia said that Labour would make good on the SNP's broken promise to scrap the unfair council tax.

Under our plans the average property in Scotland would pay £111 less, with the average property in Glasgow paying £135 less.

The SNP campaigned in 2007 and 2011 on a promise to scrap the unfair council tax – but instead have opted to tinker with the council tax.

Under our fair property tax 80% of households, nearly 2 million, will pay less than they do just now with those in the most valuable properties paying more. Our system raises the same amount of money as the current council tax scheme, but in a fairer way.

Today Kezia Dugdale visited the Punjabi Junction cafe in Leith where she said that while the wealthiest in Scotland will see their taxes increase, those on the lowest incomes will be better off under Labour's plans for income tax and a new fair property tax. 

Read more:http://www.scottishlabour.org.uk/blog/entry/low-paid-better-off-under-labours-tax-plans
link_name: Low paid better off under Labour's tax plans

We will fight to keep CalMac in public hands

A Scottish Labour Government will suspend the current tender of the CalMac ferry routes and take the case to the EU to keep CalMac public.

CalMac ferries are more than just a mode of transport  - they are lifeline links for families and communities.

Last November, the SNP voted against Labour's call to halt the CalMac privatisation process, despite previous promises they would not put the services out to tender.

It's not too late to act. A Scottish Labour Government will suspend the tender process and work to guarantee the Clyde and Hebrides services will not be privatised by taking the case to the EU.

Those who live on Arran and the other islands deserve to know these vital services are safe.

#BothVotesLabour

On the 10th anniversary of the introduction of the concessionary bus pass, we made clear our pledge to regulate the bus industry to introduce an integrated transport system.

The SNP supported regulation of the bus industry before entering government in 2007 but have failed to introduce any form of regulation since.

Millionaire bus tycoon Sir Brian Souter has donated more than £2 million to the SNP since 2007.

With new powers coming to Scotland, parties have to be willing to stand up to vested interests. The SNP's failure to back taxing the 1% more with a 50p top rate of income tax is a sign that they aren't prepared to do that.

status_message:
Today Ian Murray MP and Cat Headley, candidate for Edinburgh Western, visited Entrepreneurial Spark in Edinburgh to highlight the positive economic impact of our plan to use the powers to invest in education and invest in our future.

Ian said: "We have made a very simple pledge – a Scottish Labour Government will stop the cuts and low income earners will not pay a penny more than they do today. 

"That means Tory austerity in Scotland can come to an end, because we will be bold enough to use the new powers to invest in the future. Unlike the SNP, we will never use the Scottish Parliament as a conveyor belt for Tory cuts.

"Those at the bottom won't pay a penny more than they do now and will be protected from cuts with Labour. 

"With the SNP those at the top won't pay a penny more than they do now and the poorest will pay the price with deeper cuts."

Find out more:
http://www.scottishlabour.org.uk/blog/entry/the-snps-position-on-cuts-is-utterly-hypocritical#sthash.0xheX5Ra.dpuf

We would ask the Children's Commissioner to review the Named Person legislation. 

Kezia has highlighted parents concerns about the scheme, and has said that a Labour Government would pause the process so that parent's concerns can be addressed.

"This entire process has been an absolute mess and it has caused a lot of anxiety for parents. 

"Parents have lost confidence in the named person scheme. We support the principle behind this policy, which is that the children at risk of falling through the cracks get the support they need. 

"But the introduction of the policy has been botched by the SNP – from the communication of this policy to parents to the way the legislation has been presented to Parliament.

"A Labour Government will pause the process and ask the Children's Commissioner to carry out a full review, so that the concerns of parents can be addressed. 

"If improvements are recommended then they will be implemented. The introduction of the named person scheme has been a shambles by the SNP and as a result of that what we are forgetting is that we need to make sure children who need extra support get that. That should be the priority."
 
Find out more: http://www.scottishlabour.org.uk/blog/entry/comment-on-named-person-scheme

This morning, Kezia visited a nursery in East Lothian and spoke abou how the SNP won't ask the richest to pay their fair share of tax - but they will ask our children to pay the price of cuts.

Last week Nicola Sturgeon said setting a 50p top rate of tax would be "daft" and "reckless". Speaking on BBC Good Morning Scotland today the SNP Leader confirmed that she would not introduce a 50p tax on the richest few.

The First Minister confirmed her opposition to increasing taxes on the wealthiest few to invest more in education in an interview where she also effectively conceded that she had cut teacher numbers by 4,000. 

Kezia said:
"With each passing day the SNP's excuses for not reversing George Osborne's tax cut for the richest few look thinner than ever. The SNP won't ask the richest 1% to pay more tax but they will ask our children to pay the price of cuts.

"We have been very clear – Labour will ask those earning more than £150,000 a year to pay a 50p top rate of tax so we can invest in our schools. If we want Scotland to have a world class education system then somebody has to pay for it. We need to invest in our schools, not carry on with the cuts."

We will use the powers to stop the cuts. The SNP refuse to ask the top 1% to pay their fair share to stop the cuts. We would use the 50p top tax rate to invest in our schools. 

Through the new powers being devolved the Scottish Parliament will be able to reverse George Osborne's tax cut for those earning more than £150,000 a year. The Chancellor reduced the top rate of tax from 50p to 45p. 

At the General Election last year, the SNP made a manifesto promise to back a 50p top rate of tax for those earning more than £150,000. On the day the Smith Agreement was announced, Nicola Sturgeon committed herself to a 50p rate. However, yesterday when announcing the tax rates she would actually set the First Minister refused to reverse George Osborne's tax cut for the richest few. 

Kezia has challenged Nicola Sturgeon to back Labour's pledge to protect all education spending. This has been a key ask of the teachers' union EIS. Yet again Nicola Sturgeon refused to commit to protecting education spending, meaning even more cuts to schools, colleges and universities. 

Kezia Dugdale said: 

"The new powers of the Scottish Parliament mean we can stop the cuts. We can take a different path to the Tories and end austerity in Scotland. 

"Faced with a choice between using the powers of this place and passing on Tory austerity, Labour will use our powers.  

"Labour will use the powers to protect education spending in real terms over the next five years. Nicola Sturgeon has campaigned for years on the mantra that more powers mean fewer cuts, but now she has the powers she refuses to use them to stop the cuts to schools.  

"Labour will reverse George Osborne's tax cut for the richest 1% and set a 50p top rate of tax for those earning more than £150,000 a year. Until yesterday the SNP agreed with us but now they refuse to ask the richest 1% to pay their fair share to stop the cuts to schools and vital public services."

As Scottish Labour prepares for the election in May we know the kind of Scotland we want to create, where everyone has a fair chance to play their part. We already have some exciting ideas about what needs to be done but we know that in every community in Scotland there are people who have great ideas that could make a big difference. status_message:
When it comes to women's representation we don't just offer warm words, we deliver 

Scottish Labour go into the Holyrood election with the most gender balanced slate of candidates of every major political party in Scotland 💪

Ahead of our conference this weekend, 53% of Labour's constituency candidates will be women, along with 50% of list candidates.

Factoring in candidates who stand on the list as well as the constituency Labour has 108 unique candidates with a perfect 50:50 split.

Kezia said:

"When it comes to women's representation Labour doesn't just offer warm words, we deliver. Our list of candidates is a perfect 50:50 split between men and women. It is a list that looks like Scotland.

"Right now the glass ceiling for women in Scotland has a few cracks in it, but we are nowhere near to breaking it. We should never make the mistake of thinking a woman in Bute House or three female party leaders means it's job done for women's equality in Scotland.

"Today I am throwing the gauntlet down to the other parties. If you really believe in better representation of women you need to actually follow through, not just pose for a photo op."

http://www.scottishlabour.org.uk/blog/entry/when-it-comes-to-womens-representation-labour-doesnt-just-offer-warm-words

"Labour has been resolute on tax - we will reverse George Osborne's tax cut for higher rate payers and we will ask the richest few earning more than £150,000 a year to pay more so we can invest in our schools and nurseries. 

"Despite saying they think George Osborne is wrong, we have yet to see any details of the SNP's tax plan for the top 15% and Nicola Sturgeon won't even commit to her manifesto pledge from last year on the 50p tax.

"We have a choice. We can wring our hands and wave the cuts through or we can use the new tax powers to end austerity. Scottish Labour will use the powers to stop the cuts."

status_message:
Scotland's political parties should vow to use the new powers to build a fairer country.
 
Labour would use the new powers over tax to invest in education to cut the attainment gap, and new powers over social security to build a fairer Scottish welfare state.

Commenting as Scottish Parliament debated the Scotland Bill, Opportunity spokesperson and Smith Commission member Iain Gray outlined how Labour would use the new powers to cut the gap between the richest and the rest in our classrooms.
  
We have set out different choices on tax to stop the cuts to schools and other vital services – including setting a Scottish rate of Income Tax  one penny higher than the rate set by George Osborne; setting a 50p top rate of tax for those earning more than £150,000 to invest extra in education; and not passing on George Osborne's increase in the threshold for the top 15% of earners.
 
The SNP have not spelled out what they would do on tax – except back the Tory plan not to increase the basic rate.
 
Our Opportunity spokesperson Iain Gray said:
 
"The new powers coming to Scotland means we have the chance to radically change Scotland and build a fairer country. Every party should vow to use these powers to stop the cuts and grow our economy.
 
"The most important economic investment we can make in our country's future is in education, and the most important policy we can pursue in education is cutting the gap between the richest and the rest. There is now no reason for the SNP to cut hundreds of millions from schools and local services.
 
"Faced with the choice between using the powers of the Parliament to invest in the future or carrying on with the SNP's cuts to schools, Labour will always choose to use the powers.
 
"Under Labour's plans to use the new powers the wealthiest few would pay the most, including those earning more than £150,000 a year. I want to use that extra money to put power into the hands of teachers, who are best placed to take decisions about how we close the gap between the richest and the rest.
 
"We can use the new powers over social security to lift children out of poverty. Labour will abolish the bedroom tax, uprate carer's allowance, introduce a full grant for looked after children entering higher education and double the sure start maternity grant for new parents who are struggling."

http://www.scottishlabour.org.uk/blog/entry/every-party-should-vow-to-use-these-powers-to-build-a-fairer-scotland

ANNOUNCED TODAY: Our plan for a transport system that works for commuters, not transport bosses 

The next Scottish Labour Government would regulate Scottish bus services for the first time and legislate for an integrated transport system where one smart ticket can take you across Scotland via all modes of transport.

The integrated transport system would be underpinned by new regulation which would provide transport authorities with powers to set service levels and group profitable routes with non-profitable routes.

Despite promising a nationwide smartcard by 2014, the SNP Government has still failed to deliver it with testing only beginning recently and no date set for full roll out. Scottish Labour's plans would be compulsory, apply to all transport operators and would see the roll out within the first year of the new Government and the switch to contactless credit or debit cards by the end of the next Parliament.

Announcing the policy, Kezia said:
"We need a transport system that works for commuters, not transport bosses. Right now, the Scottish transport system is a patchwork of services and many areas are left behind with no decent provision. That's why we will legislate for an integrated transport system with regulated bus services and one smart ticket that can take you across Scotland.

"People should be able to travel the length and breadth of our country with one card in their pocket. In 2012, we were told this wasn't far off, but in 2016 we're still waiting. London has had a single smartcard for thirteen years and have recently started taking payments using contactless credit and debit cards. The technology exists – all we need is the political will to deliver it.

"The last Labour Scottish Government introduced concessionary travel for older people – a policy we are proud of. The next Labour Government will make it even easier for more people to move from their own cars to a fully integrated public transport system. Times are tough for people, we will make it cheaper and easier to get to work."

Learn more: http://www.scottishlabour.org.uk/blog/entry/we-need-a-transport-system-that-works-for-commuters-not-transport-bosses#sthash.1d3TsarO.dpuf

status_message:
The SNP Government's plan to cut air passenger duty will help the richest few. Instead of cutting it, we would use the money to help young people aspire to own their own home again. 

Analysis from the Office for National Statistics has shown that the SNP's plan to halve air passenger duty would save the top 20% of earners £73 whilst the poorest would save just £4.50.

With new powers coming to Scotland over tax, we have challenged the SNP to ditch the tax breaks for the richest and instead back Labour's plans to use money to help first time buyers save towards a deposit. 

Our plan would effectively double the help first time buyers currently receive towards saving for a deposit. 

A person who currently saves through a first-time buyer ISA up to the value of £3,000 would be entitled to an additional £3,000 from a Scottish Labour Government to help toward the cost of a deposit to buy a property. 

Under this plan, the average couple each saving £100 a month would be able to save for a £15,000 deposit within three years.   

Find out more about our plan here: http://www.scottishlabour.org.uk/blog/entry/today-we-set-out-an-ambitious-plan-to-help-first-time-buyers-in-scotland#sthash.twqWfIJO.dpuf

The SNP's decision to cut the fuel poverty budget will leave over 200,000 in the cold.

The SNP Budget cut spending for fuel poverty measures by £15 million – a 13% cut to the current budget.

224,00 pensioners in Scotland live in fuel poverty according to the latest figures.

Cuts to the fuel poverty budget were short-sighted and counterproductive as it was likely to increase the strain on public services like the NHS and social care with more pensioners at risk.

We've pledged a Warm Homes Act, which will change building and planning regulations to tackle fuel poverty.

Our Communities spokesperson Ken Macintosh said:

"Over 200,000 pensioners in Scotland live in fuel poverty. The response of the SNP government to that figure is not to take action, but to slash the budget for fuel poverty measures by more than 10%.

"The last Labour-led Government set an ambitious target to eradicate fuel poverty by 2016. The SNP are going to miss that target by a mile.

"These short-sighted cuts are simply wrong from the SNP. Cutting fuel poverty measures will simply increase the already huge pressure on public services like the NHS and social care services.

"Labour will deliver a ground-breaking Scottish Warm Homes Act. This will deliver the changes we need to see in planning and building regulations to tackle fuel poverty. 

"The SNP may miss the 2016 target, but Scotland must not give up on ending fuel poverty." 

http://www.scottishlabour.org.uk/blog/entry/the-snp-will-leave-over-200000-pensioners-in-the-cold-with-cuts#sthash.sZHaWsai.dpuf

Nicola Sturgeon says that education is her top priority, but the SNP Government's own figures show that spending has been cut by 10% since 2007.

The First Minister wants to dismiss her cuts to education, but behind every number is someone whose life has been turned upside down because of decisions made by the SNP Government.

People in our schools are losing their jobs and the staff that remain face even greater pressure. It's our young people who will lose out because of this government's cuts to education.

For years the First Minister said independence was the way to stop the cuts, but that argument is now dead. Labour have set out a plan to use the powers of this Parliament to stop the cuts - but on the 50p tax, the higher rate threshold and the 1p plan she has voted it down each and every time.

It's time for Nicola Sturgeon to spell out exactly what she will do to stop the cuts.

We have set out different choices on tax to stop the cuts to schools and other vital services – including setting a Scottish rate of Income Tax 1p higher than the rate set by George Osborne; set a 50p top rate of tax for those earning more than £150,000 to invest more in education; and not passing on George Osborne's increase in the threshold for the top 15% of earners. 

www.scottishlabour.org.uk/KidsNotCuts

status_message:
We will reform education to give every young person the skills they need to compete for the jobs of the future.

On a visit to Peebles High School today Kezia discussed with senior pupils her plans to reform the senior phase of school with a Scottish Graduation Certificate.

The Scottish Graduation Certificate would be a qualification gained at the senior phase of secondary school and would involve vocational courses, work experience and traditional exams. This would allow formal recognition for young people with fewer traditional qualifications.

We would also reform spending plans for cutting the gap between the richest and the rest with a Fair Start Fund to cut the attainment gap.

Scottish Labour would use the new powers coming to Scotland to ask those earning more than £150,000 a year to pay a 50p top rate of income tax to invest in our schools to establish a Fair Start Fund. This would mean an extra £1000 for every primary pupil from a deprived background in Scotland.

Under Labour's plans for Fair Start Fund, Schools in the borders would receive an extra £1.2 million in funding for the attainment gap.

Labour would give head teachers the power to decide how the extra money is spent. That could be additional teachers, classroom assistants or other initiative that have evidenced outcomes.

In their latest budget, Borders Council has been forced to cut their budget for closing the gap by 43%.

Kezia said:

"I want every young person to have the best possible start in life, that is why I will reform education to give everyone the skills they need to compete for the jobs of the future.

"Our schools need investment and reform, not more SNP cuts. Labour will establish a  Scottish Graduation Certificate for the thousands of young people across the country who have skills and talents that simply aren't recognised by today's education system.

"Labour will also reform the funding for tackling the gap between the richest and the rest.

"This is a vital investment in the future of our country. It is what will allow our young people to compete for the jobs of the future and grow our economy for decades to come.

"Faced with the choice between using the powers of the Parliament to invest in the future or carrying on with the SNP's cuts to schools, Labour will always choose to use the powers.

"Labour would ask the wealthiest few would pay the most, including those earning more than £150,000 a year. We would give that extra money to put power into the hands of teachers, who are best placed to take decisions about how we close the gap between the richest and the rest. Our teachers have the knowledge, they just need the funding to cut the gap between the richest and the rest – Labour will deliver it."

Today, the SNP Government published Scotland's annual accounts.

On the #GERS figures, Kezia said:

"These figures from the SNP Government show once and for all the devastating impact leaving the UK would have had on Scotland's finances.

"The fact that the cuts that would have been needed after separation would have been five times more than those being imposed now by George Osborne gives a sense of the impact on our schools and hospitals. People were misled by the SNP in the run-up to the referendum and that is unforgivable.

"Voting to stay in the UK and the recent fiscal framework deal means that the Barnett formula is protected. The new consensus in Scottish politics around the principle of no detriment and the value of pooling and sharing resources must extend to all constitutional choices.

"We avoided these massive cuts by voting to remain in the UK and we can avoid the cuts that are actually taking place to schools and other vital public services now by voting Labour.

"We have put forward a bold plan to stop the SNP's cuts by setting a Scottish rate of Income Tax just 1p higher than the rate set by George Osborne. 

"Faced with the choice between using the powers of the Scottish Parliament to invest in the future and grow our economy or carrying on with the SNP's cuts to schools, we choose to use the powers."

Find out more: http://www.scottishlabour.org.uk/blog/entry/kezia-comments-on-gers-figures#sthash.FYxcvPIS.dpuf

WATCH NOW: Community group Watch Us Grow explain how the SNP's cuts will impact them. 

The SNP are in complete and utter denial about the damage their budget will do to Scotland.

As Councils up and down the country are forced to make swingeing cuts to jobs and services because of the SNP budget, for John Swinney to claim that any impact would be minimal is simply laughable.

We know that Cosla have estimated that 15,000 jobs could go because of SNP cuts. These are cuts which will undermine the future of our country.  There is another way, we can do it differently.

Faced with the choice between SNP cuts and using the powers of the Scottish Parliament, Scottish Labour would use our powers. We would set the Scottish rate of income tax 1 penny higher than George Osborne and stop the cuts that will cost thousands of jobs and undermine our children's future.

Last week at First Minister's Questions today Kezia challenged the First Minister to back her pledge to ban fracking in Scotland.

Despite the SNP campaigning on an anti-fracking platform last May, Nicola Sturgeon refused to back Labour's pledge.

The SNP are only committed to a temporary freeze on fracking, not an outright ban, and have commissioned major research on how to clean up after fracking.

The SNP Government are also not releasing minutes of meetings with business who stand to gain millions from fracking in Scotland.

Minutes before First Minister's Questions, SNP Energy Minister Fergus Ewing said the SNP Government's current approach is to pursue fracking based on evidence and no conclusions had been reached.
