This International Women's Day let's #PledgeForParity, not only in our representation but in our policies. #IWD2016

http://www.scottishlabour.org.uk/blog/entry/international-womens-day-2016#sthash.HgO1VgyE.dpuf

Happy International Women's Day! 

Read below what Kez has written on this year's theme of #PledgeForParity - and how this #IWD we should 'pledge for parity', not only in our representation but in our policies.
 ↓

"The theme for this year's International Women's Day is "pledge for parity". It continues to disappoint me that despite it being 2016 we are still fighting for 52% of the global population to be treated as equals.

"We have made significant strides for women, but many of those strides make up the tapestry of feminist history that has come before us, led by the Emmeline Pankhursts and Mary Barbours of the world. In recent years those strides have become baby steps.

"Look at the representation of women in the Scottish Parliament. In 2003, women made up 40% of the total numbers of MSPs. Today, that figure is just 35%. It is likely that the upcoming Scottish Parliament election will see this increase again, but these figures illustrate exactly why we cannot assume that the fight for female equality is won. It's an ongoing battle. That's why I set up the Women 5050 campaign with Alison Johnstone MSP, a cross party effort campaigning for at least 50% of the candidates in local and national elections to be women.

"The fact that the three main political parties in Scotland are led by women is a good thing, but can you hand on heart say that has dramatically altered the life of women in Scotland? I don't think we can. Having more women in parliament, and crucially a diverse set of women, will make a difference, but only if it impacts the decisions that are made there.

"The recently passed SNP Government budget was one of cuts and passing-the-buck austerity. Hundreds of millions of pounds has been cut from schools and local services. And which section of society relies on public services most? Women.

"Since the Tories came to power in Westminster with their austerity agenda, experts have shown time and again that women disproportionately bare the front of cuts. The same outcome will be felt by women in Scotland with this SNP budget.

"Last week it was reported that widening access initiatives across universities to help those from the poorest backgrounds enter higher education are being cut. Who suffers most? Those who are furthest from entering education and employment - working class and BME women.

"We have childcare policy which is rooted in a rigid approach of hours per child.  The Care Inspectorate released a report just last week calling childcare in Scotland inflexible and unworkable. It found that some local authorities were only able to provide 3 hour blocks of care. The way to support mothers back into work isn't to give them just three hours of childcare a day.

"It is not enough, though, for me to just point out the failures of the government. I have been setting out the bold action I would take to improve the lives of women across Scotland.

"The powers of the Scottish Parliament are substantial and I think it's about time the government started making the most of them. I want to set the Scottish rate of Income Tax just 1p higher than the rate set by George Osborne so we can stop the SNP's cuts to schools and childcare. The wealthiest would pay the most, but everybody would benefit.

"I also want to use the new social security powers to lift children out of poverty. The Sure Start Maternity Grant has been stuck at £500 for years. Scottish Labour would more than double this to £1030, so that new mums can buy the things their children need – nappies, a pram, a cot and much more.

"This International Women's Day let's 'pledge for parity', not only in our representation but in our policies."

REVEALED TODAY: More than 92,000 patients have waited longer than the SNP's interim 4 hour A&E target since weekly in the last year

New analysis after the first anniversary of weekly A&E reporting last Tuesday reveals:

- 92,208 patients waited longer than 4 hours in the past year8,278 patients have waited more than 8 hours in the past year1,284 patients have waited longer than 12 hours in the past year

- More than 7,500 patients have waited more than 4 hours at the £850m flagship Glasgow Queen Elizabeth University Hospital since it opened in May last year.

- More than 1,337 patients waited more than 8 hours at the Royal Edinburgh Infirmary and nearly 350 patients waited more than 12 hours at Hairmyres Hospital in East Kilbride

These figures should act as a 'wake-up call' to the SNP Government about their sticking plaster approach to the NHS and called for greater investment in primary and social care to take the pressure off of our hospitals.

Our Public Services spokesperson Dr Richard Simpson, a former GP with over thirty years' experience said:

"Now more than ever we need a health service based on patient need not the ability to pay.

"Under the SNP government NHS staff are overworked and undervalued, with only a third believing there are enough of them to do their jobs properly.

"The cost of the SNP not supporting our NHS staff is missed waiting times, with tens of thousands of Scots waiting longer than they should for the treatment they need.

"The SNP have had nearly a decade in power and a majority in parliament but won't give our NHS the support it needs to hit the targets they impose.

"Hundreds of millions of pounds of SNP cuts to local services will only increase the pressure on our hospitals. We don't have to accept those cuts.

"Faced with the choice between cuts to public services and using the powers of the Scottish Parliament, Labour would use the powers to invest."

Read more: http://www.scottishlabour.org.uk/blog/entry/more-than-92000-patients-have-waited-longer-than-the-snp-ae-target-in-the-l#sthash.1m0wNt8S.dpuf

→ Nicola Sturgeon is planning to give the green light to fracking if she is re-elected in May.
→ Kezia challenged her to back her pledge to ban fracking in Scotland.
→ Despite the SNP campaigning on an anti-fracking platform last May, Nicola Sturgeon refused to back Labour's pledge.

The SNP are only committed to a temporary freeze on fracking, not an outright ban, and have commissioned major research on how to clean up after fracking.

Minutes before FMQs, SNP Energy Minister Fergus Ewing said the SNP Government's current approach is to pursue fracking based on evidence and no conclusions had been reached.

Kez said:

"The SNP say fracking is bad. They have imposed a temporary freeze. A big report has been ordered. But it looks like they are going to go ahead and do it anyway.

"All across the country SNP candidates are telling voters that there will be no fracking under the SNP. The same people who promised Scots they'd scrap the council tax.

"Scottish Labour will go into the election with a very clear manifesto commitment. We will oppose fracking.

"A moratorium is not an outright ban; it's only a temporary stoppage.

"Her maybes aye, maybes naw response can mean only one thing – Nicola Sturgeon plans to give the green light if she is re-elected in May."

"The rights of Scottish workers must be defended."

Learn more about Kezia's speech to USDAW conference today 

http://www.scottishlabour.org.uk/blog/entry/the-rights-of-scottish-workers-must-be-defended

Kezia has revealed the extent of the cuts that Scotland will face under another SNP Government, and accused them of a "dereliction of duty" as they fail to spell out the truth of their spending cuts.

Speaking to party activists and supporters in Glasgow, she said that non protected spending including schools, transport and legal aid faced cuts of 16% over the next Parliament, following a cut of 5.4% in last week's budget.

Labour would use the new powers of the Scottish Parliament to "break with Tory austerity" and ensure that the education budget is protected over the lifetime of the next Parliament.

Kezia said:
"The debate on tax that began with our alternative to this austerity budget hasn't gone away. In fact, it is only just beginning. Why? Because with agreement on new powers no party seeking office can ignore the big choice at this election: Are we going to accept the billions of pounds of cuts to come or are we going to use the powers?

"As their own spending plans stand, with the new powers the Scottish Parliament is now guaranteed, the SNP would make cuts of £2.2billion to non-protected departments by 2020.

"We have challenged the SNP again and again on why it is that the NHS, police and small business support are guaranteed to be protected from cuts in their spending plans for the next 5 years but education, we have now confirmed in a parliamentary vote, is not.

"Fiscal analysis by IPPR Scotland shows that this means cuts of 16% to those areas not protected. To put this in context, the austerity budget just passed by the SNP cut those areas by 5.4%.

"Let me be clear, because our opponents will use any ambiguity to distract from the big questions they must answer: our argument is not that those priorities the SNP set out should not be protected. We would also protect NHS spending in real terms over the next parliament, for example. What we are saying is that cuts of this scale to transport, legal aid, the environment, culture, universities, skills, and above all, schools, are simply unacceptable.

"We must prioritise education because our nation's economic prosperity depends on it. We cannot compete on low skills and low wages. On productivity the UK still ranks in the bottom half of industrialised nations – and Scotland lags behind the UK. We risk being left further behind in the global economic race. Improving productivity is an urgent national need.

"We simply cannot go on cutting education and skills ever more deeply. In my last speech I pointed out that education has been cut by the SNP. The First Minister has vehemently denied this when I confronted her at First Minister's Questions about it. But look at the facts.

"The official figures show that local education budgets have been cut in every year since the SNP was re-elected.

"By £272 million in 11/12, then by £100 million, then £147 million and £20 million. A total real terms cut to local education of around half a billion pounds since Nicola Sturgeon was re-elected.

"That is why we have been so strong, not just in arguing for additional resources, but in arguing for the ways in which these resources can be generated.

"Without significant new revenues, which the SNP have yet to identify, a re-elected SNP would be faced with a stark choice: cut education again and again or cut those other departments by huge amounts.

"If they do plan to protect education, despite voting against it in parliament this month, then you would expect to see honest plans set out by Ministers in other departments for completely reassessing what they are able to deliver as their budgets are cut by hundreds of millions. But you don't. There is total silence about the scale of cuts to come.

"It isn't just that avoiding this truth before an election is dishonest, it is a dereliction of duty by the government.

"In our new powerful Scotland we can do things differently, we should do things differently and we must.

"We would break from the austerity of the Tories and pursue a different economic vision based on investment in education, skills and raising productivity."

http://www.scottishlabour.org.uk/blog/entry/kezias-speech-a-real-choice-real-change-now#sthash.LuG2dWjY.dpuf

With the devolution of the social security we have a real opportunity to do things differently 

Speaking in this afternoon's debate on social security, our Equalities Spokesperson Neil Findlay said that there is consensus between Labour and the SNP on introducing a fairer system, but the SNP have not outlined how they will pay for their plans.
 
He said:
 
"With the devolution of social security we have a real opportunity to do things differently.
 
"A strong foundation is vital to the creation of any new system but what is more important is what is built on top those foundations and how any new system is financed.
 
"We want to see child poverty at the centre of any system. One in four children in Scotland are affected by poverty – 220,000 of our fellow citizens. That is a collective shame that none of us can wash our hands of.
 
"We want to lift children out of poverty, so we will stop SNP cuts to schools and use social security powers to make life better for families.
 
"Scottish Labour will offer children leaving care and going into higher education a full grant, giving them the best opportunity to complete their studies and move on in life.
 
"We will raise the level of Carer's Allowance to match the level of Jobseeker's Allowance, and we will more than double the level of maternity grant to £1,030, helping struggling mums with the cost of a new baby.
 
"We will also use the new powers to formally abolish the Tory bedroom tax in Scotland.
 
"Until the SNP show how they will pay for the extra things they say they want to do their plans will lack any credibility."

http://www.scottishlabour.org.uk/blog/entry/with-the-devolution-of-the-social-security-we-have-a-real-opportunity-to-do

This morning in Glasgow, Kezia made a speech outlining how SNP dishonesty on cuts is a dereliction of duty - and what our alternative plan to austerity is. 

Kezia said that non protected spending including schools, transport and legal aid faced cuts of 16% over the next Parliament, following a cut of 5.4% in last week's budget.

Labour would use the new powers of the Scottish Parliament to "break with Tory austerity" and ensure that the education budget is protected over the lifetime of the next Parliament.

Here's some of what Kezia said - you can read the full speech over on our blog: 

"We have challenged the SNP again and again on why it is that the NHS, police and small business support are guaranteed to be protected from cuts in their spending plans for the next 5 years but education, we have now confirmed in a parliamentary vote, is not.

"Fiscal analysis by IPPR Scotland shows that this means cuts of 16% to those areas not protected. To put this in context, the austerity budget just passed by the SNP cut those areas by 5.4%. 

"Let me be clear, because our opponents will use any ambiguity to distract from the big questions they must answer: our argument is not that those priorities the SNP set out should not be protected. We would also protect NHS spending in real terms over the next parliament, for example. What we are saying is that cuts of this scale to transport, legal aid, the environment, culture, universities, skills, and above all, schools, are simply unacceptable.

"We must prioritise education because our nation's economic prosperity depends on it. We cannot compete on low skills and low wages. On productivity the UK still ranks in the bottom half of industrialised nations – and Scotland lags behind the UK. We risk being left further behind in the global economic race. Improving productivity is an urgent national need. 

"Without significant new revenues, which the SNP have yet to identify, a re-elected SNP would be faced with a stark choice: cut education again and again or cut those other departments by huge amounts. 

"If they do plan to protect education, despite voting against it in parliament this month, then you would expect to see honest plans set out by Ministers in other departments for completely reassessing what they are able to deliver as their budgets are cut by hundreds of millions. But you don't. There is total silence about the scale of cuts to come.

"It isn't just that avoiding this truth before an election is dishonest, it is a dereliction of duty by the government. 

"In our new powerful Scotland we can do things differently, we should do things differently and we must." 

#KidsNotCuts #bothvoteslabour 

http://www.scottishlabour.org.uk/blog/entry/kezias-speech-a-real-choice-real-change-now
link_name: SNP dishonesty on cuts is a dereliction of duty

REVEALED TODAY: More than half a million bed days lost to delayed discharge in 2015 – despite the SNP Government in Edinburgh promising to eradicate it by the end of the year. 

New analysis has found that 580,919 days were lost to delayed discharge in 2015. Delayed discharge is when a patient is clinically ready to be released from hospital but isn't. 

A year ago SNP Health Minister Shona Robison pledged to eradicate delayed discharge by the end of the year, and gave a personal commitment to deal with delayed discharge in the 2014 Programme for Government when she was first appointed Health Minister.

The figure shows the failure of the SNP's crisis management approach to our NHS, and warned that hundreds of millions of pounds of cuts to public services in the SNP budget will increase the strain on our hospitals. 

Our Public Services spokesperson Dr Richard Simpson, a former GP with thirty years' experience, said:   

"SNP Health Minister Shona Robison promised to eradicate delayed discharge from our health service. That promise hasn't just been broken, it has been smashed to pieces. 

"More than half a million bed days lost to delayed discharge is nothing other than complete and utter failure from a SNP Government who promised to get rid of the problem completely. 

"This goes to the heart of the SNP's crisis management of our NHS. Failing to deal with delayed discharge means that fewer patients have the dignity of receiving care in their homes and the queues at A&E get longer, which increases pressure on NHS staff. 

"The hundreds of millions of pounds of cuts in the SNP budget will only increase the strain on our NHS. 

"Cuts to the councils that provide care and other services to vulnerable Scots is a completely short-sighted way to handle our health and care service. 

"These cuts aren't necessary. Instead we can use the powers of the Scottish Parliament to make different tax choices from the SNP and Tories so we can invest in the future. Investing will stop the cuts and give our NHS, established in the 1940s, the tools and resources it needs to deal with the challenges of the 2040s."

http://www.scottishlabour.org.uk/blog/entry/more-than-half-a-million-bed-days-lost-to-delayed-discharge-in-2015

status_message:
SHARE: This afternoon, Kez spoke at the Aberdeen and Grampian Chamber of Commerce 'Meet the Leader' event about the impact of the oil price on the North East of Scotland. 

The plummeting oil price has had a traumatic impact on the economy of the North East.

Kez said: 
"I was born in Aberdeen and as a student at the University of Aberdeen I spent my summers packing food boxes for the oil rigs offshore and working in local bars and cafes. 

"I know from personal experience just how important the oil industry is, not just for those who work directly in the oil and gas business but also for those in the supply chain and the local community.

"Thousands of jobs have been lost and firms have gone out of business. This is one of the toughest times the oil and gas industry has ever faced. The new analysis produced today by the independent experts at the Scottish Parliament paints a stark picture of the devastating toll the oil price crash has taken on the area.

"Despite that, there can still be a bright future for the industry and for the North East as a whole. With the right government support, the investment can return and jobs can be saved.

"The UK Government's Budget will be announced in a few weeks time. I want the Chancellor to use his Budget as an opportunity to demonstrate confidence in the long term future of the oil and gas industry by stepping up and playing his part.

"Whether that's through the fiscal regime to attract greater investment or in support for developing what could be a thriving decommissioning industry, there is a responsibility on the UK Government to act.

"The SNP Government must do much more too. Their response to the current problems in the oil industry began at a snail's pace, because to acknowledge the scale of the challenges here was too politically inconvenient. Eventually support to help people back into work was launched, but it has fallen far short of what is needed. 

"Both the UK and Scottish Governments must step up and secure the bright future we all want to see for the North East."

READ: In today's Press and Journal, Kezia talks about how it's time to secure a bright future for the north-east 

https://www.pressandjournal.co.uk/fp/news/politics/holyrood/845682/opinion-time-to-secure-bright-future-for-north-east/
link_name: Kezia Dugdale: 'Time to secure bright future for north-east' - Press and Journal

Commenting on the news that a deal has been reached on the fiscal framework, Kezia has said:

"I welcome the news that an agreement has been reached on the fiscal framework. This is a historic moment for Scotland and one that we should all celebrate.

"Scottish Labour's position has been clear all along – we would only support a deal that protected the Barnett formula which has benefited generations of Scots. It appears that this deal does exactly that and has our support.

"Now that an agreement has been reached every single political party in Scotland must focus on what we can do with these major new powers. The opportunities they provide are huge – we can use the new tax and welfare powers to bring an end to Tory austerity and build a fairer country.

"I want to use the new tax powers to make fairer choices. That means we can ask the richest few to pay a little bit more so we can invest in education and help first time buyers double their deposit by not implementing the SNP's planned airline ticket tax cut.

"Scottish Labour has already transformed the debate in Scottish politics by setting out our bold plan to set a Scottish rate of Income Tax 1p higher than that set by George Osborne so we can stop the cuts to schools and other vital public services. Faced with a choice between using the powers of our Parliament to invest in the future or carrying on with the SNP's cuts to schools, we choose to use the powers.

"Scottish politics will never be the same again thanks to these new powers. We have entered a new and exciting era of devolution."

Find out more about our plan here: www.scottishlabour.org.uk/KidsNotCuts

BREAKING: New expert evidence has again confirmed that setting a Scottish rate of Income Tax 1p higher than that set by George Osborne is fair.

Ahead of the final vote on the Budget in the Scottish Parliament on Wednesday, new analysis by the independent experts at the Scottish Parliament Information Centre (SPICe) shows that under Labour's plan around two-thirds (64%) of the increase would be paid by richest 20% of households. The SPICe analysis also confirms that if a Scottish rate of Income Tax was set 1p higher, 92% of the increase would be paid by households in the top half of earners.

Households in the bottom half of earners in Scotland would pay less than 10% of the increase. However, under Labour's plan those income taxpayers earning less than £20,000 a year – including pensioners - would receive an annual £100 payment to ensure they did not pay a single penny more. Many income taxpayers earning less than £20,000 a year would end up better off thanks to this payment.

The SNP's Budget for 2016/17 is set to cuts hundreds of millions of pounds from schools and other vital public services. Under plans set out by Labour these cuts could be avoided and education spending protected in real terms over the next five years. The SNP stood shoulder to shoulder with the Tories to vote for cuts to schools and against protecting education spending in real terms.

Separate analysis by the experts at SPICe confirms that unprotected areas – including education – could face cuts of 16% over the next five years under the SNP's plans. That would mean cuts to local authority education budgets worth almost £800 million a year by 2019/20.

Kezia has said:

"This new expert evidence proves beyond all doubt once and for all that Labour's plan to set a Scottish rate of Income Tax just 1p higher than that set by George Osborne is fair. The fact that 92% of the cost of this plan would be paid for by the top half of earners in Scotland shows that it is the right thing to do.

"The SNP are planning on cutting hundreds of millions of pounds from education and other essential public services so that people on six figure salaries don't have to pay a bit more in tax. That's just not fair. I won't put the future success of our young people and our nation at risk like that.

"We know the SNP have stood shoulder to shoulder with the Tories to oppose Labour's plan to stop the cuts to schools and protect the education budget. When the Budget returns to the Scottish Parliament for its final vote on Wednesday the SNP should examine their consciences and do the right thing for the sake of Scotland's young people.  

"The Scottish Parliament has the powers now to bring an end to the cuts. We can make different choices from those of George Osborne. Faced with the choice between using the powers of our Parliament to invest in the future prosperity of our country or cutting the budget for schools and other services, we choose to use the powers.

"If the SNP vote for these hundreds of millions of pounds of cuts to schools and other public services on Wednesday they will be selling out the people of Scotland."

Read more here: http://www.scottishlabour.org.uk/blog/entry/new-expert-evidence-confirms-1p-tax-rise-is-fair

Read Kezia's comment on the announcement of the EU referendum date by the Prime Minister:
 
"The best way to address the major challenges we face – climate change, the threat of terrorism, the migration crisis and global economic problems – is by being part of the wider European Union.
 
"There is a strong socialist case for staying in the EU. Working in solidarity with the other nations of the EU secures vital rights for workers and greater opportunities for our young people. We should celebrate and build on that, not walk away from it.
 
"Now that the Prime Minister has agreed his package of reforms and a date has been set for the referendum, those of us who back staying in the EU must get on and make the positive case for that. We must put process arguments about any deal or date behind us.
 
"Labour is Scotland's internationalist party. We believe working in solidarity with other nations makes us stronger.  We will be enthusiastic leaders of this campaign."

status_message:
Nicola Sturgeon is breaking her promise to families with cuts to schools and local services.

As the deadline for Scottish Councils to sign up to the SNP Government's deal of hundreds of millions of pounds of cuts to schools and local services looms, Kez will visit a nursery the First Minister has previously visited to promote her childcare promises.

The SNP budget includes a 57% cut to council budgets to build the new nurseries needed to meet the SNP's childcare pledge to provide 600 hours of free childcare a year. 

Kez has said:

"Nicola Sturgeon made a clear promise to families across Scotland – she would stand up against austerity and invest in the future.

"Instead today she will force councils across Scotland to sign up to hundreds of millions of pounds of cuts or face sanctions of hundreds of millions more.

"Those cuts will be devastating to schools and children services across Scotland. Rather than delivering Nicola Sturgeon's promises on childcare her budget will slash investment in our children's future.

"The SNP's childcare plans require hundreds of new nurseries to be built across Scotland but the SNP budget slashes the funding to build those nurseries more than 50%.

"Faced with the choice between huge cuts to schools and local services or using the powers of the Scottish Parliament Labour would use the powers to stop the cuts.

"We would set the Scottish rate of income tax 1 penny higher than George Osborne and raise hundreds of millions more to invest in the future of our children and the future of our country."

status_message:
Nicola Sturgeon has sold out the people who need her most by imposing hundreds of millions of pounds of cuts to schools and local public services, Kezia said today in #FMQs.

Here's what happened today:
Speaking at First Minister's Questions, Kezia said the SNP's vote against her plan to use the powers of the Scottish Parliament to stop cuts means they have been found out.

Earlier this week Kezia set out a plan to set the Scottish rate of income tax 1p higher than that set by George Osborne.

This would mean the hundreds of millions of pounds of cuts proposed by the SNP Government's budget for 2016/17 could be avoided.

To ensure low income taxpayers receive a boost, a £100 payment would be introduced for those earning less than £20,000. This would be administered by local authorities. Council leaders across Scotland have confirmed this is possible.

Experts and trade unions have also said using the income tax power is a progressive measure as the richest would pay the most. 

Even SNP Minister John Swinney has previously described it as progressive.

Yesterday, the SNP and the Tories stood 'shoulder to shoulder' to vote against Labour's plan to stop the cuts.

Here's what Kezia has said:
"Nicola Sturgeon has built her career on telling us that more powers mean fewer cuts, yet she refuses to use the powers when it really matters. She has staked her reputation on improving education, yet she cuts school budgets rather than using the powers of the Scottish Parliament.

"Nicola Sturgeon has sold herself as the radical alternative to Tory austerity, but yesterday she sold out the people who need her most.

"At the stroke of a pen the First Minister could stop the hundreds of millions of pounds worth of cuts and thousands of job losses, but faced with the choice between using the powers of this Parliament and hundreds of millions of pounds of cuts she chose austerity.

"After this week people across Scotland are left asking why Nicola Sturgeon won't just use her power to do the right thing."

Read more: http://www.scottishlabour.org.uk/blog/entry/nicola-sturgeon-has-sold-out-the-people-who-need-her-most#sthash.579U7ryJ.dpuf

Today, hundreds gathered outside the Scottish Parliament to protest against the SNP's cuts to local budgets. 

John Swinney's budget for 2016/17 will see local authority funding cut by hundreds of millions of pounds in one year alone.

Labour leaders of councils across Scotland have made it clear - the SNP's budget cuts could have "potentially devastating consequences" for local budges for schools and nurseries.   

Kezia has set out a bold plan to amend the SNP's Budget so Scotland can avoid cuts to schools and vital local public services.

In a speech in Edinburgh yesterday, she revealed the party will table an amendment to the SNP's Budget calling for a Scottish rate of income tax to be set at 11p – 1p higher than that set by George Osborne and John Swinney. 

This measure would raise half a billion pounds, more than enough to avoid the hundreds of millions of pounds worth of spending cuts proposed in the SNP's Draft Budget – cuts that would have devastating consequences for schools and others vital public services.

This amendment will be voted on in the Scottish Parliament today at Stage 1 of the Budget debate.

Find out more about our plan here: http://www.scottishlabour.org.uk/blog/entry/this-is-our-plan-to-avoid-snp-cuts-and-invest-in-the-future
link_name: Photos from Scottish Labour Party's post

status_message:
This morning, Kez visited a school in Cowdenbeath, ahead of a vote in the Scottish Parliament this afternoon. MSPs will vote on our plan to set an 11p Scottish rate of income tax to avoid SNP cuts to schools and other vital services.

Find out more about our plan here: http://www.scottishlabour.org.uk/blog/entry/this-is-our-plan-to-avoid-snp-cuts-and-invest-in-the-future

WATCH: Today, Kez has set out our bold plan to stop SNP cuts to local budgets and invest in the future. 

Find out more here: http://www.scottishlabour.org.uk/blog/entry/this-is-our-plan-to-avoid-snp-cuts-and-invest-in-the-future#sthash.sYSHCPdv.dpuf

Given the choice between using our powers or making cuts to our children's future, we choose to use our powers.

We will tear up this SNP budget that simply manages Tory cuts and instead use the power we have to set the Scottish rate of income tax one pence higher than the rate set by George Osborne. 

This will provide an extra half a billion pounds a year to invest in the future.

This choice we make today on the Scottish rate of income tax would provide a half a billion pounds more to invest in our children's future. It enables us to stop cuts to schools and other vital public services, and to guarantee that spending on education will be protected in real terms in the next five years.

To make sure that the lowest paid workers don't lose out, we would introduce a new payment of £100 to those working taxpayers earning less than £20,000 a year, administered through local councils. Under our plan up to 810,000 workers would either be unaffected or actually be better off. 
 
Income tax is a progressive measure, since the wealthiest will pay the most. Under our tax and rebate plan, someone on the living wage would be £51 a year better off. A worker earning £30,000 a year would only pay £3.65 a week extra, I will pay an extra £40 a month and someone earning the same £144,687 salary as the First Minister would pay an extra £1,447 a year.

Find out more about our plan here: http://www.scottishlabour.org.uk/blog/entry/this-is-our-plan-to-avoid-snp-cuts-and-invest-in-the-future#sthash.tPvG8tLm.dpuf

Follow Kez's speech in Edinburgh live on our Twitter from 10:30am: https://twitter.com/scottishlabour

status_message:
The Labour leaders of councils across Scotland have said the SNP Government's budget cuts could have "potentially devastating consequences" for local budgets for schools and nurseries.

John Swinney's budget for 2016/17 will see local authority funding cut by hundreds of millions of pounds in one year alone. The SNP Government's budget will also see funding for Education and Lifelong Learning cut by more than £130 million (4.4%) next year.

Yesterday, we pledged to protect education funding in real terms over the next five years. Kez will set out more details of her plan on Tuesday during a major speech in Edinburgh.

We would also introduce a Fair Start Fund, which would invest £1,000 for each deprived pupil in primary schools across the country. This money would go direct to head teachers, who would decide how the money would be spent to close the gap between the richest and the rest. The Fair Start Fund would be paid for by increasing the top rate of tax to 50p for those earning more than £150,000 a year.

Read more here: ttp://www.scottishlabour.org.uk/blog/entry/council-leaders-highlight-impact-of-snp-cuts-to-school-budgets#sthash.AljGDr1Q.dpuf

In her Daily Record column for this week, Kez speaks about how getting the best start for our young people is her priority. 

Read it here: http://www.scottishlabour.org.uk/blog/entry/getting-the-best-start-for-our-young-people-is-my-priority#sthash.HtKMCciS.dpuf

Today, Kezia has pledged that Scottish Labour will protect education funding in real terms over the next Parliament. 

The single most important investment we can make in the future of our country is in our people. Protecting the spending for our schools, colleges and universities is the way to cut the gap between the richest and the rest and give our young people the skills they need to access the jobs of tomorrow.

Nicola Sturgeon has said that education is her top priority – but her budget doesn't reflect that. She is proposing hundreds of millions of pounds worth of cuts to local services, which will hammer education budgets up and down Scotland.

The SNP Government in Edinburgh have pledged to protect health and police budgets, but not the spending on our schools for young people.

Funding education has to be a national priority again. Cuts made by the SNP to local education funding over the last nine years are already hurting our children's schools.

Cuts to education undermine the economic potential of our nation. 

The choice facing voters in the election is now clear - we can use the new powers to invest in our young people with Labour, or keep cutting school budgets with the SNP.

Scottish politics is changing. It's no longer good enough to say you are against cuts but do nothing to change things.

Read more: http://www.scottishlabour.org.uk/blog/entry/we-will-protect-the-education-budget-in-real-terms-over-the-next-five-years#sthash.HH79y7kf.dpuf

"We all have a responsibility to stand up to hate."

Marking Holocaust Memorial Day, Kezia has said:

"Over 70 years ago, the concentration camp at Auschwitz was liberated and the world saw the full consequences of the Nazis' hate and intolerance. Six million Jewish men, women and children were murdered during the Holocaust. Despite saying after the Holocaust, "Never Again", the world has watched subsequent genocides take place in Darfur, Rwanda, Bosnia and Cambodia.

"The Holocaust ended in the 'final solution' but it began with everyday abuse and assaults targeted at Jewish people simply because of their religion. This year the theme of Holocaust Memorial Day is 'Don't Stand By'. It is a reminder to people that great hate can grow from the small acts of unkindness and injustice we witness in our everyday lives and that we all have a responsibility to stand up to them."

Ahead of attending the UK National Commemorative Event in London, our Shadow Scottish Secretary, Ian Murray, said:

"It is right that each year we stop to remember those who were killed in the Holocaust and subsequent genocides. Today I will join survivors from across the UK as they remember their family, friends and loved ones who were murdered because of hate and intolerance.

"Many of the people who will attend today fled Europe and came to the UK in search of refuge and a better life. We should be proud that we welcomed people to this country – children and adults – when they needed our support. Our country has – and should continue to have – a proud tradition of not standing by when people are in need."

http://www.scottishlabour.org.uk/blog/entry/holocaust-memorial-day

Today hundreds of activists across the country will take to the streets for our first big national campaign day of the year, with 45 campaign events in every region of Scotland launching a new leaflet outlining our radical housing plan.

Find out more about the plan here: http://www.scottishlabour.org.uk/blog/entry/our-radical-housing-plan-will-support-nearly-50000-jobs-and-help-thousands

Find the nearest event near you here: http://www.scottishlabour.org.uk/page/event/search_simple

#HousetoHome

Our radical plan on housing will support nearly 50,000 jobs a year and help thousands of first-time buyers. 

Our analysis suggests that by the end of the next parliament around 17,200 first-time buyer purchases a year will benefit from our plan. 

The number of people helped will be higher as the majority will be couples buying their first home – both will receive help under Scottish Labour's plan.

This week the SNP government announced plans to cut the Help to Buy scheme.

Under the SNP Government, the number of people in Scotland aged 34 and younger who have bought their own home with a mortgage has fallen by 15%. Just 28% of those aged 16-34 in Scotland now own their home with a mortgage – the lowest level since the Scottish Parliament was established in 1999.

Labour will also take action to ban rip off rent rises in the private sector.

Today hundreds of activists across the country will take to the streets for our first big national campaign day of the year, with 45 campaign events in every region of Scotland launching a new leaflet outlining the party's radical housing plan.

Deputy Leader Alex Rowley said:

"Everybody deserves a home and a chance, but whether you are a private renter, a social tenant or looking to buy for the first time it has been a difficult few years.

"Getting it right on housing can be the key that unlocks so much opportunity for our country; we can tackle poverty and grow the economy by building more homes. New analysis shows that our plan to build 60,000 homes over the next five years will sustain thousands of jobs.

"The SNP Government in Edinburgh have turned a housing shortage into a housing crisis. Scotland has more than 150,000 people on social waiting lists, an unacceptable amount of private tenants living in poverty, whilst three quarters of non-owners feel they will never own a home. 

"That's why Scottish Labour is promising bold and radical action in every area ofr housing. We'll help first time buyers save towards a deposit with £3,000 of extra support for those who put a little aside every month.

"A whole generation of young people have been left behind by austerity and Labour will give them a chance to get on in life. So many young people in Scotland are stuck in a cycle from which they can't escape. They end up renting to save for a deposit, but the rent is so high they simply can't put enough money away. No wonder more than half see the size of a deposit as a barrier to owning a home.

"For those living in the private rented sector we'll ban rip off rent rises to stop bad landlords hitting tenants with unfair rent hikes.

"We'll build a minimum of 60,000 affordable homes over the next five years, 45,000 of which will be council or housing association homes. That's the figure that industry experts tell us we should be aiming for and it will begin to tackle Scotland's housing crisis.

"After nearly a decade in office and a majority in parliament the SNP have been managerial on housing. Labour's bold housing plan would build a fairer nation and a stronger Scotland."

http://www.scottishlabour.org.uk/blog/entry/our-radical-housing-plan-will-support-nearly-50000-jobs-and-help-thousands

Nicola Sturgeon's own poverty advisor has rightly said that affordable, flexible childcare is key to helping people out of poverty. 

The SNP's solution to the problems with childcare in Scotland is to slash the budgets for childcare and local services. Only in the world of the SNP will that deliver a childcare revolution. 

Kez revealed how the SNP's childcare plan is just a big con. She highlighted: 

→ SNP Government cuts to council funding to deliver on Nicola Sturgeon's pledge to provide 600 hours of free childcare a year
→ Figures which confirm that allocations to councils to deliver on the SNP's childcare pledge has fallen by £10.5 million (5.3%).

Despite not meeting existing pledges, Nicola Sturgeon has promised every child 1140 hours of free childcare by 2020. 

The campaign group Fair Funding For Our Kids has confirmed this would require the equivalent of 650 new nurseries to be built, and mean allocation for an extra 26,000 children. 

Kez said today that the SNP's plan to deliver this isn't credible because they are cutting half a billion pounds from local services in the next year alone. 

"Cuts to local services will hurt the poorest most. Those children who are already at a disadvantage risk getting left even further behind. 

"Nicola Sturgeon wants to be judged on her record – on childcare she has failed to deliver on promises, cut budgets and let parents down. It's clear that instead of delivering what families need the SNP's childcare plan is just a great big con."

It shows exactly where her priorities lie that she refuses to back a living wage for care workers.

John Swinney should be honest about the impact of his cuts 

TO LOCAL GOVERNMENT →
The SNP plan to cut more than £500 million from local government in the budget. COSLA estimate this would result in 15,000 job losses. 

The cuts to local services such as schools are short-sighted, and would hinder Scotland's ability to give our young people the skills we need for the jobs of the future. 

Despite this, the SNP Government have denied any such cut is happening. 

In Scotland we have the chance to reject austerity and present the real change which people across Scotland are crying out for. Instead the SNP Government plan to accept Tory austerity. 

It's not credible for the First Minister to claim education is her top priority whilst simultaneously slashing local education budgets. This will have a devastating impact on our future economy if our young people are not equipped with the right skills.

TO OUR FUEL POVERTY BUDGET →
We've also revealed that the SNP plan to cut the fuel poverty budget by 13%, a cut which has since been confirmed by the independent experts at the Scottish Parliament Information Centre. 

After nearly a decade in power and a majority in parliament there are no excuses for the SNP Government. 

John Swinney should be honest that he's planning to cut the fuel poverty budget, and then spell out what that means for vulnerable people across Scotland.  

Read more here: http://www.scottishlabour.org.uk/blog/entry/john-swinney-should-be-honest-about-the-impact-of-his-cuts

New expert evidence shows Scottish education is narrowing as the attainment gap is widening

Following on from reports that the attainment gap had grown in 2015, we today published an expert submission made by Dr Jim Scott of the University of Dundee to the OECD review of Curriculum for Excellence which shows: 

→ Enrolment in National 3-5 subjects has dropped by 17% since the introduction of Curriculum for Excellence, meaning pupils are doing fewer subjects
→ Overall attainment in these subjects has dropped by 24%.
→ Both enrolment and attainment in Modern Languages is in steep decline, to the point where some subjects may no longer be viable in Scotland 

Dr Scott says "this compounds Scotland's existing problems of social justice and equality of opportunity." 

Scottish education used to be the best in the world. It should be again, with every young person getting the best possible start in life to access the jobs of tomorrow. 

One of the key strengths of the Scottish education system has always been the breadth of its curriculum. After a decade of the SNP Government in charge of our schools we are seeing Scottish education narrowing, attainment falling and some subjects are at risk of disappearing altogether. 

We warned the SNP about these problems months ago and they dismissed our evidence. Today we see that those trends have continued into the second year of the new exams. 

Nicola Sturgeon said education was her number one priority as First Minister, but after more than a year in the job we are seeing the attainment gap widening and the breadth of subjects our students are successful at narrowing. 

The First Minister can announce frameworks and testing all she likes but the reality is that we won't close the attainment gap without the proper resources. 

That's why Scottish Labour would ask those lucky enough to earn more than £150,000 a year to be a little extra to establish a Fair Start Fund. That would mean £1,000 of extra funding for every pupil in our schools from a poorer background.

Find out more: http://www.scottishlabour.org.uk/blog/entry/new-expert-evidence-shows-scottish-education-is-narrowing-as-the-attainment

The SNP are planning to cut the fuel poverty budget by £15 million in the year Scotland was supposed to hit ambitious targets to end the problem.
 
Last month the SNP Finance Minister John Swinney published his draft budget, which included a reduction in the amount of money spent on fuel poverty.
 
The independent experts at the Scottish Parliament Information Centre (Spice) have confirmed that the final fuel poverty budget for 2015/16 was £119 million. This is due to fall by £15 million in 2016/17 under the SNP's plans - a cut of 13%.
 
Under the last Labour-led Scottish Government, the Scottish Parliament passed a law to set a target to eradicate fuel poverty by 2016.
 
This target will not be met. Under the SNP, the latest figures for 2014 show no real change from the previous year with just under 35% of households in Scotland in fuel poverty.

Find out more: http://www.scottishlabour.org.uk/blog/entry/snp-plan-to-cut-fuel-poverty-budget-by-15-million-exposed

MSPs will soon debate the Transplantation (Authorisation of Removal of Organs etc.) (Scotland) Bill.

The private members bill from Scottish Labour MSP Anne McTaggart would introduce a "soft opt-out" system to Scotland which would permit the removal of organs unless the person objected during their lifetime.

The Welsh Labour Government introduced a soft opt-out system in December 2015.

The SNP should have a change of heart over their plans to delay any changes to the organ donor system in Scotland.

Evidence suggests that a move to a soft opt-out system could increase donation rates by up to 30%.

The Scottish Parliament has taken bold and radical action on health policy before, like the smoking ban. 

We need an NHS fit for the 2040s, not the 1940s. That means taking decisions for the long-term, like introducing a soft opt-out system for organ donations.

Find out more here: http://www.scottishlabour.org.uk/blog/entry/a-move-to-a-soft-opt-out-system-could-increase-donation-rates-by-up-to-30

Three quarters of young Scots who don't currently own their home believe they never will.
 
Today, we're highlighted the figures from the Halifax 'Generation Rent' report which also showed that more than half of non-owners in Scotland believe the size of a deposit is a barrier to homeownership.
 
On Tuesday we unveiled the party's first manifesto pledge for the Scottish Parliament election in May, which would take bold action to help first time buyers get on the property ladder.
 
The Halifax report confirms that the average non-owner in Scotland only saves £25 a week, the lowest figure across the UK.
 
Under our plan, those saving through the first-time buyer ISA scheme could effectively have their savings doubled. A person who currently saves through a first-time buyer ISA will receive a 25% top up from the UK government, up to the value of £3,000.
 
Find out more here: http://www.scottishlabour.org.uk/blog/entry/three-quarters-of-young-scots-who-dont-currently-own-their-home-believe-the

All it would take is a simple change of heart from the SNP Government and we could save lives across Scotland.

Evidence suggests that a move to a soft opt-out system could increase donation rates by up to 30%.

Rather than leading the UK, Scotland is now trailing behind other countries like Wales, where this system has already been introduced.

The Scottish Parliament has taken bold and radical action on health policy before, like the smoking ban. We should do so again and grasp the opportunity to deliver real change and offer real hope to Scots waiting on transplant lists today.

We need an NHS fit for the 2040s, not the 1940s. That means taking decisions for the long-term, like introducing a soft opt-out system for organ donations.

Scottish Labour MSPs will support this Bill - the question is if the SNP Government will join us in bold action that will save lives.

Today in #FMQs, Kez highlighted how young people are getting a "raw deal" under the SNP Government.

She highlighted the following statistics:
→ Under the SNP just 28% of those aged 16-34 own their home. That has fallen from 48% in 1999
→ 41% of people aged 16-34 in Scotland live in private rented accommodation, an increase from just 13% in 1999
→ It would take a couple with an average household income 10 years to save for a £15,000 deposit.

Earlier this week Kez set out a bold plan to help first time buyers.

Our plan would effectively double the help first time buyers currently receive towards saving for a deposit.

Kez said:
"Owning their own home is a key ambition for many young Scots, but for thousands of people from my generation it's just not a realistic prospect. 

"So many of our young people are stuck in a cycle from which there is little escape – they rent to save for a deposit, but the rent is so high they simply can't put enough money away. It's generation rent.

"Labour has a plan to help young people get on in life. We would encourage people to put money away if they can and in return we would help them get on the property ladder.

"Young people in Scotland are getting a raw deal under the SNP Government. They are bearing the brunt of an austerity agenda Nicola Sturgeon seems content to manage rather than change. 

"Instead of investing in their own future the hard earned cash of thousands of young people is boosting the profits of private landlords.

"Politics is all about making choices. Labour would spend money to help young people get on in life, whereas Nicola Sturgeon would rather spend that same money on a tax cut to help big airlines. 

"It's clear that whilst we are on the side of young people with ambition, the SNP are on the side of big airlines."

Find out more →

status_message:
The ambition of home ownership isn't being realised for too many young families in Scotland. The price of austerity has been that aspiration has stalled for a whole generation.

Under the SNP, the number of people in Scotland aged 34 and younger who have bought their own home with a mortgage has fallen by 15%. Just 28% of those aged 16-34 in Scotland now own their home with a mortgage – the lowest level since the Scottish Parliament was established in 1999.

In a speech in Edinburgh today, Kez set out our an ambitious plan to help first time buyers in Scotland.

Our plan would effectively double the help first time buyers currently receive towards saving for a deposit. 

A person who currently saves through a first-time buyer ISA up to the value of £3,000 would be entitled to an additional £3,000 from a Scottish Labour Government to help toward the cost of a deposit to buy a property. 

Under this plan, the average couple each saving £100 a month would be able to save for a £15,000 deposit within three years. 

Find out more here: http://www.scottishlabour.org.uk/blog/entry/today-we-set-out-an-ambitious-plan-to-help-first-time-buyers-in-scotland

Kez will be kick-starting our election campaign this week - by showing how new powers coming to Holyrood will provide a "once in a generation" opportunity to create a fairer and more prosperous Scotland.

In a speech in Edinburgh on Tuesday, she'll be setting out a major new housing policy. 

Kez said: "I am more excited about the possibilities of politics than ever. This is what I came into public life for. 

"I come from a different generation. Since I have been politically aware, I have only ever known the Scottish Parliament as the central institution of Scottish life. 

"The most important because the powers held by our parliament and by our government, and the possibilities for political change in Scotland, are greater than ever. 

"In addition to the power over the NHS, education, skills, transport, rural affairs, economic development, justice and policing, new powers over tax, borrowing and welfare will be in our hands.

"With these new powers comes a responsibility, not just to use them wisely - that is the ambition of the managerial politician - but to use them boldly. To make the most of the opportunity they bring to change our country for the better.

"As our parliament has matured and changed, so my party has had to mature. Now is the time for our parliament to come of age. It is time for a generation of change."

Happy New Year from all at Scottish Labour!

This year marked 100 years since our founder Keir Hardie's death. Watch Kez's personal tribute to him: 

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=aAgj7xFn9gw

In her New Year message for 2016, Kez has said the major new powers coming to Scotland mean the days of politicians complaining about something being wrong but doing nothing about it will come to an end:

"For the past three years at this time political leaders in Scotland have said that the following twelve months will be crucial to the future of our country. We all said it ahead of the referendum and then the General Election, and we will say it again this year. Repeating that message doesn't make it any less true.

"The election in May will be the most significant since devolution in 1999. With the major new tax and spending powers coming to the Scottish Parliament, the question won't be which politicians do voters want to allocate a big pot of money. For the first time each political party will have to say where the money they want to spend is coming from. The New Year will bring a new era in Scottish politics.

"The rules of the game are changing on Scottish politics. Saying you are for something but refusing to do anything about it just won't wash anymore. Those of us who say we are against Tory austerity will have to prove it with the decisions we take. Managing austerity isn't good enough when we will have the powers to take a different path.

"Scottish Labour has led the way by setting out how we would do things differently on tax from the Tories and the SNP. We would ask those earning more than £150,000 a year to pay a little extra in tax so we can invest in education - both the Tories and the SNP oppose this. We wouldn't follow the SNP to spend £250 million to cut the price of an airline ticket, and we don't support the Tory tax cut for higher earners.

"The differences between the parties will be clearer than ever at the election. Whilst the other parties are content to manage austerity, only Scottish Labour are bold enough and honest enough to set out the change that is needed and how we would make that happen.

"I look forward to 2016 with hope and optimism, both for the future of my party and my country. I am hopeful that the public will get the election they deserve. I believe it will be an election focused not on the constitution - even Nicola Sturgeon has said the vote won't be about another referendum - but on using the major new powers coming to Scotland to transform our nation.

"As we head into 2016 I want to wish everybody across the country a very happy and peaceful New Year."

http://www.scottishlabour.org.uk/blog/entry/the-new-year-will-bring-a-new-era-in-scottish-politics

From the whole of the Scottish Labour family - we wish you a very Merry Christmas.

Shona Robison has failed to meet her promise to eradicate delayed discharge from our NHS by the end of the year.
 
Delayed discharge is when a patient is clinically ready to be released from hospital but isn't.
 
Official figures published this week show that over 50,000 bed days were occupied by delayed discharge patients in October 2015.
 
Information available for the year shows that nearly 500,000 bed days have been lost this year to delayed discharge.  
 
In February SNP Health Minister Shona Robison pledged to eradicate delayed discharge by the end of the year, and gave a personal commitment to deal with delayed discharge in the 2014 programme for government when she was first appointed Health Minister.

As we head into winter these problems are only likely to get worse. We've called for greater investment in social care in the Scottish budget and whilst we welcome extra funding it shouldn't have taken nine years for the SNP to see the solution. The SNP voting against a living wage for care workers shows how short sighted they still are about health and social care.
 
We should be investing in our NHS for the long term to build a health service fit for the challenges of the  2040s, not the 1940s. A year on in the job, Shona Robison hasn't delivered.

http://www.scottishlabour.org.uk/blog/entry/shona-robison-fails-her-own-delayed-discharge-promise

It's time the SNP accepted responsibility for the Forth Road Bridge closure and took some action. 

We're calling on them to open up priority roads to small vans to keep small businesses moving.

The Forth Road Bridge is more than just a road connecting Fife and Edinburgh. It's a strategic asset that's at the heart of the transport infrastructure for the whole country. Thousands of people rely on it to get to and from their work every day and businesses depend on it for getting their goods and services to their customers.

In #FMQs today, Kez told the SNP that instead of trying to avoid blame, they should accept responsibility for the bridge closure 

She highlighted: 

- Minutes from a Forth Estuary Transport Authority (FETA) meeting in October 2013, which confirmed that a number of key bridge capital projects were "deferred" because of a lack of funding
- The SNP Government have cut the bridge budget by 65% since 2008 

On Tuesday SNP Transport Minister Derek Mackay said there was no link between cancelled repair works in 2010 and the bridge closure. However, on Wednesday Mr Mackay admitted that there was a link. He was recalled to Parliament to make a statement clarifying his remarks, however this only raised even further questions. 

Kez also called on the First Minister to confirm that small vans could drive along the priority route, currently reserved for buses and HGV lorries, to help small businesses struggling because of the closure. 

Nicola Sturgeon failed to confirm any details.

Under the SNP the Forth Road Bridge has suffered from budget cuts, the privatisation of services and cancelled repairs. Instead of constantly trying to avoid the blame, it's time for the SNP Government to accept responsibility.

http://www.scottishlabour.org.uk/blog/entry/the-snp-should-accept-responsibility-for-the-bridge-closure

Today, we asked the SNP to back our plan to give a fairer deal to Care Workers. This is what happened.

Here are more details of the plan: http://www.scottishlabour.org.uk/blog/entry/care-workers-deserve-the-living-wage

ANNOUNCEMENT:  We're backing a National Guarantee for Care Workers 

That means:  
→ Paying every care worker the living wage
→ Ensuring they are paid for travel cost & time
→ No zero hour contracts
→ Appropriate training for staff

We believe that care workers deserve a fair deal

Labour led Renfrewshire Council has already implemented these key targets and service users and staff are seeing the benefits with improved productivity and reduced staff turnover.
 
We'd work with local authorities, the health sector and private providers to ensure a national guarantee for care workers on terms and conditions.
 
We have to face the challenges of social care head on, so we can have a health service fit for the 2040s, not the 1940s. This is about raising standards in the industry so those who receive care get better quality care.
 
Our NHS will feel the benefit too. A motivated professional care workforce supported by real investment will keep  more patients out of hospital, giving them the dignity of care in their own home and relieving the pressure on our hospitals.
 
After eight years of excuses from the SNP Government, is time to end the sticking plaster approach to our health service and get serious about social care as a vital part of a sustainable NHS for the long term.

It's estimated that 27,000 children in Scotland have a parent or carer in prison. These children are often the forgotten victims of crime.

Thanks to Scottish Labour's consistent campaigning, today the Scottish Parliament is passing legislation that will change that. This Bill puts a duty on authorities to assess the support a child needs when a parent is imprisoned. Up until now the SNP Government hasn't even bothered to count how many children there are - that's why 27,000 is only an estimate.

Find out more here - and read what Scottish Labour MSP Mary Fee, who has campaigned tirelessly on this issue, has to say:
http://www.scottishlabour.org.uk/blog/entry/time-to-remember-the-forgotten-victims-of-crime

A soft opt-out for organ donation was recently adopted by the Welsh Government. It's a system that has previously received cross party support at Holyrood and has the backing of major health charities including the British Heart Foundation, the British Medical Association and the Scottish Kidney Federation.

Scottish Labour MSP Anne McTaggart has been campaigning tirelessly for a soft-opt out system. You can read about why it's so important Scotland doesn't get left behind on our blog today:
link_name: Opt-out organ donation would save lives

Today, Kez joined traders on Byres Road in Glasgow to support Small Business Saturday

Find out how our next manifesto will be the most pro-business in Scottish Labour history: http://www.scottishlabour.org.uk/blog/entry/our-manifesto-will-be-the-most-pro-business-ever

Today is Small Business Saturday. 

Small businesses all across Scotland generate the wealth we need to invest in the things that are important to us - an NHS fit for the 2040s, not the 1940s; closing the gap between the richest and the rest in our classrooms; and giving young families a fair chance at life.

Small Business Saturday is a chance to celebrate the risk takers, the people who take a punt by starting their own firm. That's the people who open corner shops, cafes and clothes shops, and the entrepreneurs who set up high tech firms creating the jobs of the future. 

Small businesses are the backbone of our economy. We back those who want to start their own business. 

That's why our manifesto for next year's election will be the most pro-business in Scottish Labour's history. 

Read more here: http://www.scottishlabour.org.uk/blog/entry/our-manifesto-will-be-the-most-pro-business-ever

George Osborne's u-turn on tax credits today is a significant victory for Labour and shows that our campaign worked.

We need to look carefully at the detail, in particular the impact on Universal Credit, but with this announcement working families can sleep easier tonight. 

Today's u-turn shows the difference Labour can make, even from opposition. We want to thank the Scottish Labour activists who've campaigned so hard on this issue. Today we've learn that while the SNP talks, the Labour Party acts to help working people across the country.

The Scottish steel industry can have a bright future but it needs urgent government support.

Today Kezia Dugdale met steel workers at the Dalzell plant in Motherwell, and this is what she had to say:

"This industry can have a bright future with the right support from government. Steel workers are highly skilled and make a valuable contribution to our communities. These skills and good quality jobs cannot be allowed to disappear from communities in Lanarkshire and across Scotland. 

"Nicola Sturgeon came to this plant a few weeks ago and promised steel workers that she would do everything possible to save their jobs. The clock is ticking and it's time the government delivered on these promises."

We've announced a Fair Start Fund for Scotland's poorest pupils, funded by a 50p top rate of tax for those earning more than £150,000 a year. In a different approach for Scottish schools, we will give the funding directly to the people who know best how to run schools - head teachers.

Figures collated by Friends of the Earth Scotland suggest that more than 3,500 people in Scotland die early because of exposure to toxic emissions.

36 areas across Scotland have dangerously high levels of pollution.

Our Environmental Justice Spokesperson Sarah Boyack MSP is taking the issue to Holyrood today, hightlighting the SNP Government's lack of progress on tackling dangerous air pollution levels.

Sarah's motion, 'Air Pollution in Scotland', has gained cross party support from Green, Lib Dem, Independent and SNP MSPs and will be debated before Parliament today at Holyrood. 

Speaking ahead of the debate, she said:

"Each year of inaction will see up to 3500 Scots each die from respiratory and coronary diseases as a result. Air quality is not just an environmental priority, it is a moral and public health issue which the SNP Government is failing on.

"This debate comes just weeks after the SNP Government's Cleaner Air Strategy paid lip service to the problem and kicked the issue into the long grass. They want to take 3 years to 'redesign the wheel' while they mull over the implementation of Low Emissions Zones.

"With thousands of potential deaths caused by its inaction, today I'll call on the SNP Government to conduct a Health Impact Assessment of its strategy.  

"Scotland and the UK are lagging behind Europe and Asia on Low Emissions Zones, selling Dennis' electric buses to the Chinese, while Minsters take chauffeur driven journeys up the Royal Mile.

"Today, we are calling on the SNP to conduct a Health Impact Assessment of its air pollution strategy. On APD, on climate change and now on air quality this government is showing time and again it is failing to live up to its clean and green mantra."

http://www.scottishlabour.org.uk/blog/entry/the-snp-is-failing-scots-on-air-quality-deaths

Kezia Dugdale visited pupils at Dumbarton Academy with Public Services Spokesperson Jackie Baillie this morning.

There, Kez spoke about how a government must be judged by the level of support it offers the most disadvantaged people in our society. In 2013/14 just 156 young people who were in care went on to higher education. We will change that. Kez has announced that a Scottish Labour Government will award student grant support of £6,000 a year to anybody who comes from care and manages to fight their way to higher education.

This is what Kez had to say ahead of her visit to Dumbarton Academy: 

"A government must be judged by how it supports the most disadvantaged people in our society, and they don't come much more disadvantaged than young people in care. We need to close the gap between the richest and the rest, so that care leavers can have as many opportunities to get on in life as any other young person.

"Too often we simply forget about them. Not necessarily out of malice or intent, but because they don't have enough people to speak up on their behalf. Whether because of neglect or circumstance, these are young people who grow up without the support network other talented young people take for granted, through no fault of their own.

"The reality is that young care leavers are more likely to go to jail than university. We need to reverse that trend, and the way to do that is to make it easier for care leavers to go on to higher education.

"Scottish Labour have a plan introduce full grant support, worth £6000 a year, for looked after young people who have the talent to go on to higher education. The SNP Government should use their existing attainment fund to introduce this plan.

"Politics is all about making choices. When we decide how to spend public money we are making clear our priorities. Giving young people the best start in life is my priority."
link_name: Photos from Scottish Labour Party's post

Kez visited Trinity High School in Rutherglen this morning and spoke to Modern Studies pupils about three big issues of the day:

→ Tax Credits
→ Steel
→ Refugee Crisis

Find out what Kez had to say...

Today, MSPs will vote on a Scottish Labour motion which calls for the major new powers coming to Holyrood to be used to restore the money lost through tax credits for working families in Scotland.
 
The vote on tax credits will be an important moment in the history of devolution. At long last everybody in Scottish politics is going to have to start talking about the responsibilities they do have, and how they would transform the lives of people in this country. 
 
If the SNP do not vote for this motion to restore the money lost through tax credits, it will confirm once and for all that the politics of grievance is more important to them than helping working families in Scotland.
 
Tax credits work. The UK Labour Government introduced them to support people who go out to work each day and do the best by their families. And a Scottish Labour Government would use the new powers coming to Scotland to restore the money lost through tax credits if George Osborne goes ahead with his plan to cut them.
 
We know the powers to restore the money lost through tax credits are coming and we know the money is there to fund them if people are willing to make difficult choices. 
 
Scottish Labour has been very clear about the choices we would make - we would not carry out the SNP's plan for a tax cut for airline operators and we wouldn't implement Tory plans for a tax cut for those paying the higher rate. 
 
When working families face a struggle to put food on the table it just isn't right to spend more money helping the better off.

"Today's debate on tax credits is a defining moment for Holyrood."
↓
Read this from Kez in today's Huffington Post 
http://www.huffingtonpost.co.uk/kezia-dugdale/tax-credits-scotland_b_8465808.html?utm_hp_ref=uk&ncid=tweetlnkushpmg00000067

A Commission on Health Inequalities was set up by Unison and Neil Findlay MSP in 2013. The Commission has now reported back and makes clear that a coordinated response, using a range of policy-approaches, is needed to address the scourge of health inequalities in Scotland.

We agree and Scottish Labour will take up the challenge set out in the report to tackle health inequality.

"I have set out my plan for a more autonomous Scottish Labour Party. It will be a radical shake up that means the primary focus of Scottish Labour will be on Holyrood and the powers our parliament has to make Scotland a fairer place to live."

Kez sets out her radical plan for a more autonomous Scottish Labour Party in today's Daily Record:
link_name: More autonomy for Scottish Labour will make us fit for the future

status_message:
Today Kez announced her plans for more party autonomy: 

"The key goal for my leadership is to renew the Scottish Labour Party, to show that we are changing. More autonomy for Scottish Labour is central to achieving that goal. 

"With these reforms there will be be no doubt that the main focus of Scottish Labour will be on Holyrood, where the key decisions affecting the daily lives of Scots are made. It won't be the Commons, the Lords or the European Parliament. They are important, of course, but the most important focus of Scottish Labour will be on using the powers at Holyrood to transform the lives of people in Scotland.

"I am proud to be part of a UK-wide movement and believe that we can achieve more together than we ever could alone. As a socialist, standing together with friends, neighbours and colleagues across the UK to make our country better is a good thing.

"We have to recognise, though, that the UK is changing and so must the Labour Party. I want the Scottish Labour Party to lead the way, and would encourage other parts of the UK Labour Party to set out their case for more autonomy."

Read more here: http://labourlist.org/2015/10/more-autonomy-is-vital-for-the-scottish-labour-party/

"I just have my gut instinct"

Read Kez's interview with Dani Garavelli in today's Scotsman

link_name: Kezia Dugdale interview: 'I just have my gut instinct'

The amount of money spent on private agency nursing staff has quadrupled under the SNP since 2011, new analysis from Scottish Labour can reveal.

This week Audit Scotland revealed that spending on agency staff last year hit £16 million. In 2011 that figure was £3.9 million.

This huge increase in spending on private agency staff is simply another example of the SNP Government's sticking plaster approach to the NHS. The SNP Government has failed to form any long term plan to protect our NHS.

Find out more about the Audit Scotland report →

status_message:
NHS staff in Scotland work incredibly hard to deliver the care that Scots need, but it is clear that even at the new £850 million flagship hospital things are going wrong. 

Just last week we saw the hospital needing urgent specialist support for the second time in just four months. 

We asked SNP Health Minister Shona Robison back in May to consider pausing the transfer of patients to ease the burden on the new hospital, but she said no. 

Now we see thousands of patients waiting longer than they should have to for care. It's just not good enough and SNP Ministers must get a grip.
  
This is the reality of decisions made by the SNP Government in Edinburgh about our NHS. 

The SNP Government is guilty of squeezing health spending in Scotland harder than even the Tories in England.

Read more here: http://www.scottishlabour.org.uk/blog/entry/these-problems-with-our-ae-need-to-be-fixed-before-winter-comes

Judge me on my record, says Nicola Sturgeon: Nearly 4,000 patients have waited more than four hours in A&E at Scotland's newest hospital since May

http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-scotland-glasgow-west-34560615
link_name: Scottish Labour highlights Glasgow hospital's A&E wait numbers - BBC News

status_message:
A fortnight ago Kez wrote for the Daily Record to say that our country needs a proper industrial strategy. You can catch up on that article below. 

But, today we've heard that even more jobs in the steel industry will be lost - including at plants in Scotland.

This is what Kez had to say today:

"Reports of job losses in our steel industry are very worrying. I have been in touch with the trade unions today about this and have been assured that they will be working hard over the weekend to secure as many jobs as possible.   

"If the reports are true it could signal the end of the steel industry in Scotland. That would not only be the end of an era, it would be devastating for the workers, their families and the local economies. 

"The full force of the UK and Scottish Governments must be used to support the workers and the industry. With the right support a lifeline can be offered to secure not only existing jobs but also create a bright future for manufacturing in this country. 

"Those involved cannot be left to fend for themselves."
link_name: "A proper industrial strategy means we can support the hi-tech jobs of the future" writes Kez

Last night we raised more than £1,000 for Edinburgh Rape Crisis Centre at our special sell-out screening of Suffragette.

The hit film gave Labour members and supporters an opportunity to look back at how far the women's movement has come in the past 100 years - but how far we still have to go.

Leader Kezia Dugdale was joined by three brilliant panellists for a Q&A ahead of the film; former MP and women's acitivst Maria Fyfe, awarding-winning journalist Gina Davidson and the first woman president of NUS Scotland in 10 years, Vonnie Sandlan.

Thank you to everyone who came to our celebration of women's activism, and for your generous donations.

Check out these pictures of our panel - in their great Votes for Women sashes!

"Fake claims to be on the side of working people while robbing three million low paid families of £1,300 a year with the Tax Credit cuts.

This coming Monday evening we will be hosting a very special event at the Dominion Cinema in Edinburgh.

To coincide with new film Suffragette, starring Helena Bonham Careter, Carey Mulligan, Meryl Streep and more, Scottish Labour will host a private screening on the same day it is released nationwide.

Prior the screening ticket-holders will be invited to a panel discussion and Q&A with our Leader Kezia Dugdale, former MP and women's activist Maria Fyfe, journalist Gina Davidson and President of NUS Scotland Vonnie Sandlan on "Women's equality: how far we have come and how far we have to go." Proceeds from the ticket sales will be donated to Edinburgh Rape Crisis Centre.
