www.scottishlabour.org.uk/suffragette

In today's Great British Bake Off Final...

Kez and Opportunity Spokesperson Iain Gray baked carrot cake today with students at Ross High School, and they met with a Modern Studies class.

Neither Kez or Iain will be in tonight's TV final, but they did speak to students about using their voices to build a fairer Scotland.

This is what Kez had to say this morning:

"I want every single young person to have the best possible start in life, and we can make that happen with more young people registered to vote, using their vote and organising for causes that are important to them.

"The hard truth is that young people's issues will only be at the top of the political agenda as pensioners' issues have always been if politicians are forced to take notice of young voters.

"Politics for too long has been seen as the preserve of the middle aged and the middle class. I want that to change. I want every young person to use their voice to build a fairer Scotland next year.

"Scotland is leading the way with 16 and 17 year olds able to vote in the Scottish Parliament elections next year but political parties need to catch up and engage with these new voters.  

"The decisions made as a result of those elections will impact every young person in this country, from the quality of education and skills they can access, the opportunities they have to find jobs, to the NHS, public transport and housing. Next year's election will be a defining one for Scotland's young people."

Not registered to vote? Do it now, it only takes five minutes: https://www.gov.uk/register-to-vote
link_name: Photos from Scottish Labour Party's post

Today the Human Trafficking Bill passed in the Scottish Parliament. It was introduced into Parliament by Labour's Equality Spokesperson Jenny Marra MSP and calls on the Scottish Government to create a robust anti-slavery strategy in Scotland.

During the unfolding refugee crisis we at Scottish Labour have demonstrated our commitment to welcoming those who are fleeing persecution; and to guarantee their safety. The refugee crisis has illustrated the need to take action to stop trafficking.

We congratulate Jenny on the passing of this important Bill that she introduced, but this legislation is just a start in bringing those who exploit the most vulnerable to justice.

Read Jenny's statement below:

New UK Labour Leader Jeremy Corbyn visited Edinburgh today to meet with Scottish Labour Leader Kez Dugdale and other members of the labour movement.

Jeremy said that "Labour is the party of working people again" and backed Kez's plans for fair taxes to close the gap between the richest and the rest in Scotland's classrooms.

Whilst walking between meetings Kez and Jeremy stopped to speak to passers-by - and quite a few photographers decided to join them too...

status_message: To everyone celebrating Eid Al-Adha today, Eid Mubarak from Scottish Labour

Today Kez met with First Minister of Wales Carwyn Jones and they agreed to work closely together to share ideas about making sure every young person can achieve their potential no matter their background.

To find out more about what action the Welsh Labour Government are taking to tackle inequality Kez visited a Barnardo's centre in Cardiff. There she saw the Families First programme in action. This is a scheme that aims to improve public services for families, to tackle the inequalities that arise from living in poverty, and to help all families realise their potential. In the last year alone the Labour Welsh Government invested £47 million in this programme.

These photos show Kez meeting First Minister Carwyn Jones and making Eid cards with children at the Barnado's centre ahead of celebrations later this week.
link_name: Photos from Scottish Labour Party's post

Today, Kez recommited Scottish Labour to protecting the NHS from the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP) - as she signed up to a Unite the Union campaign calling for action from David Cameron.

The NHS is one of Labour's proudest achievements, and we will always do everything in our power to protect it.

We cannot allow a situation where our public healthcare is fair game for private healthcare companies. We must do everything we can to protect the NHS.

It's time to start governing for a better Scotland

In this week's #FMQs, Kez challenged Nicola Sturgeon to make improving the life chances of young Scots a priority rather than trying to find triggers for another referendum.

→ More than 6,000 children in Scotland finish primary school unable to read properly
→ Private school pupils are twice as likely to get an A in their Highers than state school pupils
→ A young person from a rich background is twice as likely to go on to higher education than someone from a poorer background

The SNP Government should focus on making a material difference to the lives of young Scots rather than making a shopping list of material changes they think will justify another referendum.

We're calling for all the revenue from VAT raised in Scotland to stay in Scotland.

Shadow Scottish Secretary Ian Murray is tabling this in an amendment to the Scotland Bill today. If this Labour proposal is accepted it will deliver an extra £5 billion to Scotland.

This is what Ian had to say about Labour's vision for the Scotland Bill:

"Labour is the party of devolution. It was a Labour Government, after a decision by people across Scotland, that created the Scottish Parliament in 1999 and we will show that same ambition and determination in pushing for more powers in the Scotland Bill.

Hi, I'm Graeme Pearson, Scottish Labour's Spokesperson for Justice and a former senior police officer.

Public confidence in Scotland's police service is at a real low. Officers and staff work hard every single day to keep us safe, but they are being let down because of decisions made by those at the top and SNP Government ministers. 

People need to know that the police will be there to help when they are needed. That's just not happening at the moment.

A couple of weeks ago we launched a major review of Scotland's policing. This is an opportunity to rebuild public confidence in our police force after a summer of crisis. 

Do you have any questions about policing in Scotland? Or suggestions for how it can improve?

Leave your questions below and I will be responding to them over the course of this week.

Congratulations to Jeremy Corbyn - the new leader of the UK Labour Party
 
This what our Leader Kezia Dugdale had to say:

"Today shows politics has changed. People are calling for radical change and straight talk. Jeremy's election shows that the party has listened to that call, and I look forward to working with him and meeting him to discuss his priorities later today.

"I have already said that I want people to take another look at the Labour Party. I want to say that again today. I hope that those who were lost to us in the past will start to listen again as both Jeremy and I put forward radical policies that we hope will win back support for Labour.

"We've now got the chance for a fresh start and new leadership in both Scotland and across the UK. I've said I want my leadership to be about shaking up the establishment in Scotland, and Jeremy wants to do the same across the UK. What people want is real change – not just in their politics, but in their lives. Today offers the chance for that change."

status_message:
On a visit to Selex ES today, Kez highlighted figures from Close the Gap which showed that:
→ Fewer than 3% of chartered civil engineers in Scotland are women
→ Just 10% of senior managers in science engineering and technology professions are women

Scotland's future prosperity depends on redoubling our efforts in science and technology, but that cannot happen unless we boost participation in science, technology, engineering and mathematics subjects amongst women. 

Kez said:

"Closing the door on talented women is bad for our economy and our future.  Experts have said that if Scotland invests in engineers we could reap a £1.7 billion windfall. To do this, we need nearly 150,000 new engineers over the next few years.

"Scotland can be a leading nation in the world of Science again, but not if we continue to exclude half the population from that effort.

"That's why it's so important we encourage more women into science and engineering. Investing in these jobs doesn't start with modern apprenticeships; it begins in our primary schools with the basics like literacy and numeracy.

"That's why Scottish Labour continues to campaign and highlight the attainment gap in our schools. It's holding us back today and it will hold back our country tomorrow."

Read more here: http://www.scottishlabour.org.uk/blog/entry/Scotland-should-look-to-boost-the-number-of-women-going-into-STEM-subjects

status_message:
It's official: Kezia today confirmed that at least half of Scottish Labour's group of new candidates at next year's Holyrood elections will be female.

She joined women in Govan this morning to get started on smashing inequality. 

On the announcement, Kezia said: 
"I want to attract new talent and fresh faces to Scottish Labour for next year's election. My commitment today is that at least half of Scottish Labour's new candidates will be women."

"There is so much to do to shatter the glass ceiling for women in Scotland. Having a parliament that looks like the country we seek to represent is a good start. I hope other parties rise to challenge as Scottish Labour has."

Investigative journalist Eamon O'Connor told the Scotland 2015 programme last night that he believed Police Scotland had been illegally monitoring his communications.
 
We've tabled a Parliamentary motion calling for transparency from the SNP Government over alleged spying on journalists and their sources by Police Scotland.
 
SNP ministers have to break their silence about these shocking allegations. This goes to the heart of public trust in our police and our government.

status_message:
Today at 5pm we'll be hosting a Q&A on this Facebook Page with David Stewart MSP, our transport spokesperson, all about keeping CalMac ferry services in public hands.

Don't forget to check back in later this afternoon and comment with your question!

We've tabled a Parliamentary motion calling for transparency from the SNP Government over alleged spying on journalists and their sources by Police Scotland. 

Last weekend's Sunday Herald reported that Police Scotland is one of two forces in the UK which has illegally monitored communications between journalists and their sources. 

Both Police Scotland and the SNP Government have refused to deny the reports and failed to put up a spokesperson for BBC Radio Scotland to discuss the issue this morning.  

These are very serious allegations and it's not good enough for Nicola Sturgeon to maintain complete silence. 

When it was revealed that GCHQ had changed its rules to allow it to spy on MSPs the SNP Government was quite rightly outraged. 

That same outrage should apply to alleged spying by Police Scotland on journalists and their sources.  

We need full transparency from the First Minister about exactly what SNP Government ministers know about these allegations and whether they have authorised any surveillance of journalists and their sources by Police Scotland.

We've lodged a motion calling for transparency from the SNP Government over alleged spying on journalists and their sources by Police Scotland. 

Read more about it in the Evening Times:

http://www.eveningtimes.co.uk/news/13575184.Labour_lodge_motion_over_claims_Police_Scotland_has_been__spying_and_snooping__on_journalists/

We want to wish our congratulations to all pupils who collected their results today.

Today, these pupils have been vindicated and now we must make sure next year's pupils don't have to go through the same thing.

Read about it here:
http://www.scottishlabour.org.uk/blog/entry/scotlands-pupils-have-been-vindicated

Audit Scotland must urgently investigate the SNP government's mismanagement of capital project funding in Scotland.

An investigation by the Guardian has uncovered proposals from the Scottish Futures Trust  to increase private sector involvement in capital projects (for example, projects to build schools, hospitals and roads). This could lead to spiralling costs and billions of pounds worth of extra debt for future generations.

Before the SNP took office Nicola Sturgeon claimed the SNP's changes would save the taxpayer money and see an increase in public sector involvement. 

But in fact, this is the complete opposite.

The SNP must be honest with the people of Scotland about their plans for fracking and unconventional gas.
 
Today the Herald reports that Cluff Natural Resources, a firm who want to ignite coal reserves under the Firth of Forth, expects to get the go-ahead within months.
 
The process, known as underground coal gasification, has been described as 'frightening and experimental" by Friends of the Earth Scotland.
 
Earlier this month the SNP were accused of hypocrisy as Ineos Chief Executive Jim Ratcliffe revealed the SNP Government had told him they were not opposed to fracking, despite the party producing anti-fracking material in the run up to the general election.
 
SNP Ministers have been dodging the important questions on the unconventional oil and gas moratorium for months.
 
Under our plan no fracking will take place in Scotland without the local community affected giving its approval in a referendum. We will give Scots a local veto over fracking. It is clear that the SNP will not.

http://www.heraldscotland.com/news/13496760.SNP_faces_new_calls_to_block_Firth_of_Forth_coal_gas_plans/
link_name: SNP faces new calls to block Firth of Forth coal gas plans

WATCH: Today sees Stage 3 of the Community Empowerment Bill debated in the Scottish Parliament 

This Bill has the potential to put our local communities at the heart of decision making.

It depends on key amendments, tabled by Alex Rowley MSP, and passed by the Scottish Parliament's local government and regeneration committee, remaining in place. These are amendments which Oxfam, the Poverty Alliance and Barnardo's Scotland have strongly supported.

As organisations working with disadvantaged communities in Scotland, they believe the bill has the potential to empower communities right across the country, including those who are currently our most disempowered.

Watch the debate live here from 2.40pm: http://www.scottishparliament.tv/

Read this open letter from Oxfam, the Poverty Alliance and Barnardo's Scotland to find out why they support Scottish Labour's amendments:
http://www.scotsman.com/news/opinion/letters/people-power-1-3796184

Today's papers cover the A&E crisis at the new South Glasgow University Hospital. 

The SNP must face up to the problems in our A&E departments. 
More needs to be done to support our hard-working NHS staff.

The SNP government has failed to meet A&E targets again.

Latest A&E figures show almost one quarter of patients at the new South Glasgow University Hospital are waiting longer than four hours at A&E. 

But SNP Health Secretary Shona Robison has said the integration of hospitals in Glasgow has gone 'extremely smoothly'. Are these inevitable teething problems or is there simply not enough beds to cope with demand? 

We believe more needs to be done to support hard-working doctors and nurses.

On top of A&E waiting time targets being missed for the 295th week in a row: Scotland's newest hospital, the flagship South Glasgow University Hospital, is missing its A&E targets by a considerable margin. 

That makes it the worst performing hospital in the country for waiting times. 

Figures out today show that:
→ Only 83.2 per cent of A&E patients at the South Glasgow University Hospital were seen within four hours
→ That Greater Glasgow Health Board is the worst performing health board in the country of A&E waiting times
→ The SNP Government has missed its own target for the 295th week in a row

The SNP must address the problems in our A&E departments.

Today, Ian Murray MP has tabled an amendment to the Scotland Bill that would see the creation of an impartial and independent expert commission to assess the impact of full fiscal autonomy on Scotland's public finances.

This was submitted alongside a raft of other Scottish Labour amendments designed to improve the Scotland Bill including the devolution of more welfare powers and the establishment of a UK-wide Constitutional Convention. 

Full Fiscal Autonomy was a key pledge from the SNP during the General Election. 

If the SNP have confidence in their policy they should have no problem backing an assessment of the impact of full fiscal autonomy on Scotland's finances by an independent expert commission. 

It's time for the SNP to have the courage of their convictions on full fiscal autonomy.

Find out more about our amendments: 
http://www.scottishlabour.org.uk/blog/entry/the-snp-should-have-the-courage-of-their-convictions-on-full-fiscal-autonom#sthash.oSDc1rba.dpuf

It's #CarersWeek. The upcoming Carers Bill is an opportunity to transform the lives of carers across Scotland – and it's one we must not miss. 

Currently support for carers in Scotland is a postcode lottery. Research from Carers UK has found that nearly a third of those caring for over 35 hours a week receive no practical support with caring. 

29,000 of Scotland's carers these are young carers. We must make sure that they are still able to get the best chance in life; to be financially supported as carers and be able to access further and higher education.

New expert analysis has shown the number of candidates studying and passing a modern language has plummeted in the last year.

Research by Dr James Scott, published in the Scottish Languages Review, revealed that in the first year of the new exams:

→ The number of candidates studying Level 3/4/5 German, French or Chinese fell by 37%
→ The number of candidates passing Level 3/4/5 German, French or Chinese fell by more than 40%
→ The number of Gaelic Learners at Level 3/4/5 fell by more than 20% and the number passing these exams fell by more than a quarter

With 300,000 Scottish jobs linked to the UK's EU membership, the ability to speak other languages is key for young Scots when competing for jobs across the world.

Read more here: http://www.scottishlabour.org.uk/blog/entry/the-ability-to-speak-other-languages-is-key-for-young-Scots

Scotland's city regions need job creating powers

That's why we're delighted to have played a key role in signing Scotland's first City Deal and now in its delivery in Glasgow and the Clyde Valley.

Just a few of the improvements the City Deal is expected to make: 
→ Create 15,000 construction jobs and 28,000 permanent jobs for workers in the region
→ Invest £27 million in the Collegelands Calton Barras Action Plan
→ Develop Inchgreen as a strategic hub for renewables and specialist marine services
→ Invest £78 million in the Clyde Waterfront and Renfrew Riverside regeneration
→ Nearly £120 million will be invested in improving transport links across Lanarkshire
→ Redevelop the 81 acre Exxon Site in West Dunbartonshire to bring investment to the area and create jobs
→ Invest £30 million in Strathclyde Buses

status_message:
A better future for Scottish education is possible by taking responsibility for the failings of the present, not pointing the fingers at teachers.

Last week the SNP refused to back our plans to deliver additional investment in education by using a 50p rate of tax. 

The current scandal in attainment is no more the fault of Scotland's teachers than it is our young people. Both have been let down by an SNP Government in Edinburgh who for eight years have had failed to give education the attention it deserves.

The EIS have said that schools and teachers are committed to tackling the impact of poverty on educational attainment - but need the resources to make it happen.

Scottish Labour has a solution. 

We would use the new powers coming to Scotland to ask those who earn the most to pay a little extra to invest in our young people. Its fair taxes to help the poorest kids. 

The SNP have opposed this in the past but faced with their own record, and their new found interest, they should think again.

Read more about this story in an article from the BBC here: http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-scotland-scotland-politics-32876726

SHARE: A leading trade unionist has called on the SNP's candidate in West Dunbartonshire, Martin Docherty, to apologise after making a disgraceful slur about Clydebank shipyard workers.

The SNP candidate told a local hustings that shipyard workers "pissed" their pay packet "up against a wall".

Hugh Scullion, General Secretary of the Confederation of Shipbuilding and Engineering Unions, said:

"This is an insult to shipyard workers not just from Clydebank but across Scotland. Generations of workers did us proud. To dismiss the people who made Scotland the shipbuilding capital of the world is just not on.

"The SNP candidate in West Dunbartonshire should be ashamed of himself and apologise for these offensive comments."

REVEALED: Actions speak louder than words.

Yesterday Nicola Sturgeon made a grand announcement of her and her party's support for the women's agenda. She says her government is leading by example.

But in today's Scotland on Sunday it has been revealed that a flagship body set up by the SNP has no women on the boards of its five 'hub' companies. 

Women's equality is not about a photo-opp and grand gestures it's about the struggle of thousands of women in Scotland, and millions of women across the world, to take their rightful place in society and make sure their voices are heard.

The Labour party and movement has always known this, and acted on it when in government. Can the same really be said for Nicola Sturgeon's SNP?

How it happened: today's story on the SNP's plans for austerity that would make even the Tories blush. 

https://storify.com/scottishlabour/today-s-ifs-story

EXPERTS CONFIRM: The SNP have signed up to more austerity than the Tories. 
 
The SNP's manifesto has fallen apart today after the Institute for Fiscal Studies (IFS) exposed the impact of full fiscal responsibility within the UK.
 
In a devastating report, the impartial and independent experts at the IFS said that by the end of the decade the gap in Scotland's finances because of full fiscal responsibility is due to grow to £9.7 billion a year. 

The IFS conclude that "full fiscal responsibility would likely entail substantial spending cuts or tax rises in Scotland."
 
The IFS also demolish the SNP's repeated claim that the gap will be filled by increased economic growth and higher onshore receipts.  

Rather than close the gap, the IFS conclude the SNP's proposed tax cuts would "cost the government money, and widen rather than shrink the fiscal gap, even if they did boost growth."

READ MORE HERE: http://www.scottishlabour.org.uk/blog/entry/experts-confirm-the-snp-have-signed-up-to-austerity-worse-than-the-tories

A Labour Government will give Scotland's one million disabled people a voice.

For too many disabled people life under the Tories has been unbearable, from unfair targets for sanctions to the bedroom tax. As Jim Murphy said today "it's as if the Tories deliberately go out of their way to penalise disabled people."

Labour's plan will make life fairer for disabled people in Scotland.

Read the manifesto here:

http://www.scottishlabour.org.uk/blog/entry/a-better-future-for-disabled-people

"The battle to build a country that works for working people is the story of our movement.

And here in Scotland you have always answered the call.

When people asked a hundred years who would fight for workers' rights, it was Scottish trade unionists who said, call on me.

When people asked after the war, who will ensure education reaches all working people, it was Jennie Lee who inspired the change and said call on me.

When people asked a generation ago, who will make a minimum wage central to Labour's programme, it was John Smith who said call on me.

And then when the people of Scotland asked who will fight for and lead a Scottish Parliament, it was Donald Dewar who said call on me.

But what the history of our movement teaches us, is that it is leaders who can be the catalyst for change, but it is only with movements that change can happen.

So today I call on you.

I call on you to put an end to this government."

Read the full text of Ed Miliband's speech to the Scottish Trade Union Congress:

http://www.scottishlabour.org.uk/blog/entry/scotland-you-have-always-answered-the-call-ed-miliband

SHARE: 4 things we learnt from the SNP manifesto launch

1. The SNP's White Paper promised the referendum was a 'once in a generation' opportunity. But they've refused to rule out re-running it in their manifesto.

2. Just because you try to rename 'full fiscal autonomy' 'full financial responsibility' doesn't change anything. It would still cost Scotland £7.6 billion.

3. This is a 'say one thing do another' manifesto. They claim to support a UK-wide mansion tax, but at the same time have committed to cutting Scotland off from UK-wide taxes. They claim to be against austerity, when full fiscal autonomy would mean £7.6 billion of cuts, extra borrowing or tax increases.

4. Nicola Sturgeon extends a hand of friendship to Labour on stage - today and in last week's debate - and says it's the Tories she wants out of power, but their own event props say otherwise.

We'll keep our promise on the Vow. Will the SNP keep their promise on another referendum?

That was Kezia Dugdale's message on yesterday's Sunday Politics. 

Do you think we'll find out in their manifesto today?

"It's not really that difficult a question – will the SNP's manifesto rule out another referendum? 

After all, we were told repeatedly by Nicola Sturgeon and Alex Salmond that the referendum was a 'once in a generation' thing. 

That was their promise to the people of Scotland. 

We will keep our Vow on more powers for Scotland and sticking with the Barnett formula – will they keep their promise and rule out another referendum?"

Read Kezia Dugdale's Daily Record column here:
link_name: Kezia Dugdale: The last thing Scotland needs is another independence referendum

Today, Jim visited Social Bite in Glasgow. 

A quarter of the staff who work in Social Bite have previously been homeless, and are doing brilliant things supporting those who are still without a home. 

The SNP's reckless plans for full fiscal autonomy would turn Scotland into a Wonga economy. Nicola Sturgeon said her party would borrow to fill the annual £7.6 billion deficit created by full fiscal autonomy within the UK and scrapping the Barnett formula.

However, the SNP's assertion that Scotland could borrow continuously to fill the annual £7.6 billion deficit their policy of full fiscal autonomy creates has since been demolished by two leading Scottish economists.

We need a government that will support and go above and beyond what inspirational people, such as those at Social Bite, do. 

The choice between austerity with the SNP, or investment with Scottish Labour is now clear.

In his column in today's Evening Times Jim exposes the reality of the SNP plan for full fiscal autonomy and explains how Labour has a better plan to help Scotland's working families.

"Scratch the surface of the SNP's main General Election plan, though, and the full scale of the cuts that would be needed is eye watering.

Scottish students are having to borrow at record levels as grants are reduced and tuition remains free, even to the rich. 

The NHS is enduring big funding shortfalls."

status_message:
We're proud to have launched 'Carer's Labour Network" with Carers Champion Clare Lally. 

 We pledge:

Accountable, Transparent and Responsive support and services for Carers

Giving the Care Inspectorate responsibility over inspecting Carers services

Require Local Authorities to do yearly reports on Carer's support and services, including speaking directly to Carers: this report must be publicly available.

Commit to ensuring Young Carers get the support they need and deserve.

First step – fully commit to Scottish Youth Parliament Care. Fair. Share Champaign; Changing EMA Guidance, extending SAAS dependency grants and Young Scot concessionary travel.

Investigate what other measures can be introduced to help Young Carers access to education and training.

status_message:
Today in Blantyre, Ed Miliband laid out his contract for Scotland on why social justice is best achieved by a No and the election of a Labour government.

We will freeze energy bills  

We will raise the minimum wage

We will introduce fairer taxes, including a new lower starting rate of 10p and a new higher rate of 50p.

We will tax the bankers' bonuses and put our young people back to work. 

We will abolish the bedroom tax. Abolish it in Dundee, in Glasgow, but also in Carlisle, Newcastle and Nottingham. Because if you care about social justice you care about the poor, the disabled, the vulnerable wherever they happen to live.
